"it happened on the jellicoe road. the prettiest road i've ever seen" the only thing i'm disappointed aboutthe book is the fact that jellicoe road doesnt exist, or atleast not in australia. it is well described in the book how beautiful and magnificent this place is and when i say i *yearnedd* to see how it is in real life, i am not kidding.the first 100 pages into the book, i found myself still trying to grasp the story, not knowing where it'll lead because honestly the more i tried to expect it, the more it digressed. with all the wars with the cadets and townies that was introduced in the beginning, i thought the author will focus on that part of the story. boyyy was i wrong in the middle, the story goes softer and sweeter and i love how the friendship, secrets, and mysteries were untangled in a perfect amount of melancholy and gentleness altogether. not to forget.... JONAH GRIGGS. i havent had a fictional boy crush for so long and now i have strong infatuation for him. his firm and stern personality with the physicals of a brute... totally my style >.< oh however, i wish i couldve learned more about the school and each houses and what happened after the fire. how did the two girls discovered the tunnels and how are the wars and boundaries now that they are far from being enemiesyea i think thats about it. this is my first Marchetta's novel btw. really looking forward to read more from her <3

3.5/5I'm very torn about this book. Is it three? four? five stars?It was very confusing in how it was put together, like someone ripped out a hand full of random pages from different sections of a long story, and stapled them together in a mash-mash order.It was also frustrating how the "revelations" the book built up to were so obvious from the very beginning. Grand reveals aren't as exciting when you have been waiting for the usually-smart protagonist to finally have her "aha" moment after waiting 200 pages (and she doesn't even figure out 75% of it by herself, the rest has to be told to her).But it was still a moving book that I can't quite bring myself to rate as three stars like I had been planning. So four it is.

Classic childhood YA fave. Read it again for nostalgic reasons and to remember my writing roots - I’m a sucker for the type of gorgeous, lyrical, poetic prose that bursts out of this book. At times I had to really prompt myself to view all of this from my 15 year old self; reading this is as an adult is humbling. Some of the dialogue felt forced and unnatural, especially in how the boys interact with each other and it was somewhat off putting, if I were being hypercritical I’d say it perpetuates the toxic trope of men’s aggression and emotional repression. However, to place this within context, it matches the background of these characters. Grippingly unshakable whimsical book.

I loved the Finnikin of the rock triology so I decided to read another book by the same author. I read up to 50 pages from this book, and I was still confused about who are the characters that were being discussed in this book. Plus what was the plot!!!! I persevered and with time was able to understand the story. I laughed and cried with the main character which I find is so difficult to sense in many books.
It's been a long time since a book kept me interested all the way through...this shit is sooo good
Beautiful beyond words.. I'm crying 😭😭❤️❤️

Melina Marchetta is a genius. At the beginning of her books i always feel extremely confused: Who are all of these people? What are they talking about? Huh? But during the course of the story it just all starts to make perfect sense. Her books are so well crafted, so gripping so intense, it is incredible. So these are my thoughts on the book:The love story: Intense chemestry, amazing banter i was soooo into it.The mystery: Soooo good. Really kept me on the edge of my seat wanting to find out how all of the characters and storys tie together. The ending: Bittersweet in the best way. This book had me in tears and i loved it so much.

It feels like I just witnessed two generations grow up right in front of me. Heartbreaking and lovely, all at the same time. Found family, coming-of-age, coming to terms with the shit you've been dealt and making a life for yourself...read this if any of that appeals to you.Also,while you're reading, if you feel like you're so lost that you want to start from chapter one again to see if you missed something, you're right on track.

I’m so torn on this rating. The second half of the book was beautiful. I loved the story arc and the way the stories weave together. However, there were just a few too many secrets and I was left out of the loop a bit too much at the beginning and my fried, sleep-ridden brain got a bit frustrated. If I give this one a second read, I would be able to appreciate the first half as much as the second. Still a great book.

I was in a reading slump, otherwise I think I could have read this in a day. It starts off a little confusing, but stick with it!! Everything will come together! I loved this story. It was so heartwarming and tears were absolutely shed.
i cried... a lot

Books have made me cry before. But this is the first book that made me burst into inconsolable, from-the-gut tears.“She tells me about the time my father had a dream about me before I was born. How we were sitting in a tree and he asked me my name and I said it was Taylor.”the one bad thing I will say about this book is that I've been unable to read anything after it. it's like i've completed reading. nothing will ever ever top this.

I have read this book an embarrassing amount of times, and yet I still end up sobbing every fucking single time.Melina’s writing is amazing and On the Jellico Road has to be one of my favourite books of hers and just an all time favourite for me in general.

How does one even begin to review Jellicoe Road?Anything I type will seem not enough. If I searched for the finest combination of words and managed to come up with a pragmatic sentence like “this book was a primal example of top-notch storytelling”, it would be like diminishing the lengths of its emotional reach just to make it fit in a closed space of category, turn it into something you can shelve and put away, and it deserves more than that. Marchetta’s story was an orchestra of paradoxes that exploded and sunk into itself at the same time — it talked about love and hate, comfort and grief, harvesting and destruction, life and death. It talked about friendships and war and how sometimes it can only take one second for your entire world to fall apart, burn into dust. And I can’t even begin to express how reading it felt so heavy, like the weight of gravity was suddenly pressing down on me, and the cold melancholy it oozed out of every chapter frosted my fingertips and made me feel numb. I don’t know if my next sentence will make sense, but this was the type of story that makes you feel like you’ve drunk too much and that the world is moving too fast for your hungover brain to keep up with everything — which is good. Art means a whole lot more when it is capable of inciting emotions of that caliber in someone.Don’t ask me to explain the logistics of this book. It was confusing and a little nauseating at first, seeing the feud between the Cadets, the school and the Townies present itself with scattered pieces and chaotic figures. But trust me when I say that the unfolding of the thread that binds these three forces is an experience unlike anything you’ve read before. Through the painfully nostalgic perspective of Taylor, the story behind the accident that happened in Jellicoe Road and of the people who lost a family but gained another because of it appears like colorful dust in the air and reading about it is like trying to grab everything at once. But your hands get stained and there’s still so much to see and you want to consume this book all at once even though it’s so sad and inflammable that it hurts. I loved it so much but... Damn I need a walk-in-the-park of a read after it, an Emily in Paris but in book form, basically. It’s so funny because I remember putting it on my TBR months ago because I thought it’d be a YA-contemporary like a John Green book or something.... LOL
I almost marked it down to four stars because it was so sad, but it is truly a great book. Very life affirming. reminded me better than any book I've read recently what it feels like to be seventeen.

I saw that this book has amazing reviews, people cried and some reread it every chance they get, all I can say is I've never been so happy to finish a book and I didn't even care what happened at the end because Taylor was so unlikeable, Jonah had the worst first impression although he did grow on me and the flash backs seemed like they were all upside down. I didn't get the impression that the flashback characters were fleshed out properly, their characters were flat and forgettable. I didn't expect to dislike this so much, because the lumatere chronicles is one of my favourites.
this book just broke my heart. I feel for the characters their friendship, their found families. This book captures so much emontion and familiarity, i loved it so much.

Jellicoe Road.What. A. Book.What am I even going to say that hasn’t been said yet? I started this book literally 2 days ago and I’ve finished it. Yep. I read 400 pages in two days. Which probably won’t be something super rare on this community but I swear it is for me; not the fact that I read it fast but the fact that I literally couldn’t stop thinking about this book when I wasn’t reading. I wanted to know more. I HAD to know more and get to the bottom of these two different stories that collide together at the end.Before doing this too long, I just wanted to say that this is my new favorite standalone. Since the first page, I’ve felt the warmth and aura of the Jellicoe Road. It’s so weird because it has never happened to me before, and it was like I was there (even if it sounds so cliché), alongside Taylor, on the Prayer Tree. I could feel what Melina wanted us to feel with this book (I promise it makes sense once you read it, it’s so difficult to express with words) and the only word that comes to my mind to describe this book is: magical.I don’t want to keep going because I’m going to burst out crying again and I think I’ve cried enough. Please read this book.Thank you for reading!

I felt a lot of feelings while reading this, but one of the primary ones was exasperation. Jellicoe Road is insanely sentimental, and if you don't have a stomach for that kind of thing, this is a tough hang. It is the most YA book of all time, and I mean that in a lot of the good ways and all of the annoying ways that implies. It's not an exaggeration to say the main character has an emotional breakdown every five pages. The number of tears shed in this book could power a water park or keep a family alive in the desert. I'm all for tears, but when every moment is given equal hurricane-esque emotional weight, it's hard to take them as seriously. (Then again, that's basically what it's like to be in high school, so it's not like it's inaccurate.)The ending is really strong, and I think the afterglow skews the ratings a bit, because the rest of the book is less so. Then again, I am not 14 years old, and this book isn't for me :) So I should probably stop talking. If nothing else, this book is genuine and deeply felt.
This book gives me orange vibes but a little bit sadder 🙃

The premise of the three adolescent groups struggling to survive despite an underlying darkness of abandonment and tragedy reminded me of 'Lord of the Flies'. Marchetta is a fine writer with introspective characterisation, but at times it was difficult to follow why the characters from the three groups were so obsessed with their territorial rights and rules. Then a scene is described very effectively and Marchetta's writing skill is evident. Her experience teaching in a boarding school is also evident. But the heirarchies seemed pointless. Maybe that is the point?
Amazing! It captured to wonder of childhood and the fears of growing. It made me love all the characters and sad when someone died. Amazing.

This is such a lovely and heartbreaking story of love, loss, family and friendship. It’s both heart-wrenching and uplifting and so captivating. It has one of the strongest and most beautiful friendships I’ve ever read about.At age eleven, Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mother. At fourteen, she ran away from boarding school, only to be tracked down and brought back by a mysterious stranger. Now seventeen, Taylor’s the reluctant leader of her school’s underground community, but her closest friend and mentor is Hannah, a woman who lives on the edge of the school grounds. When Hannah disappears Taylor’s search for her unveils a truth that might not just settle her past, but also change her future.The story is told in two different timelines, the past via a manuscript that Taylor finds, and the present. It’s so well-written and planned in every little detail and so suspenseful in how it slowly reveals the connections between events in the past and present times. It’s a beautiful story about friendship, but it also deals with a lot of heavy topics such as violence, death, grief, loneliness and desire to belong, suicide and self-harm.This book is so emotional and happy and sad at the same time. I had smiles and tears all over my face while reading it. It’s a book that made me suffer and that broke my heart, but it also made me so happy and I just loved every little thing about it! I cannot even try to explain how special and wonderful this book is, more than to say that I recommend it with all my heart!
One of my absolute favourite books of all time. Absolutely incredible book. Still love it to this day.

Predictable reveals at my age, but honestly, for teens, this book is gonna pack a punch! Great atmosphere, great build-up to the final reveal, great characters, great angst and a great ending. What more can you ask from a ya?

One of the rare books that manages to capture kindness and happiness without making it sappy. A very sweet book. You really care about the characters.The adult characters are not as well done as the adolescents.

It’s been a really long time since I’ve loved a book as much as I loved this one. The writing is lyrical and the story moving, a whole universe built in just a few words. For such a sad story the writing is so hopeful, and I loved watching as each character was developed and spun into a better version of themselves. Overall, this is a book I couldn’t wait to reread as soon as I finished, and couldn’t stop thinking about when I was done. It’s truly masterful.
this book is devastatingly sad✌🏻

“i remember the tremble in my mother’s body when the midwife first placed me in her arms. i remember the feeling of slipping between those fingers. it’s like she never really managed to grab hold of me with a firmness that spoke of never letting go. it’s like she never got it right.” “it’s funny how you can forget everything except people loving you.” “want to believe in something. but love the world just the way it is.”
This book wasn't for me. I finished it though because I liked Jonah
Simply beautiful. A brilliant example of how marvelous young adult fiction can be. Raw, deep, painful. This book will tear your heart out and stitch it back up. Read, read, read!
4.5 stars.

The day before I started reading On the Jellicoe Road, I was wondering when in the world I would come across a worthy 5-star read. A day and a half later, after I turned the last page of this book, I wondered how in the world I hadn't picked it up before.If you like reads where a past story mixes with the present, this one's for you. I really appreciated the flow of the book. It was easy-paced and suspenseful enough. I didn't really like the final mystery-reveal-slash-plot-twist, but it made the story all the more unique.I've got a secret love for the kind of conflict like the "territory war" in On the Jellicoe Road. No weapons, just teens trying to outsmart each other following the idea of a war but without casualties. In this aspect, this book has got a lot of 
The War of the Buttons
 in it.IMO, the character growth throughout the story is worth the read. The dynamics. The growing friendships. The book starts cold and progresses towards warm. I can't say more (let's avoid spoilers, shall we) but there is a beautiful underlying message of how, most of the times, conflicts are unnecessary and founded on flimsy reasons. People set apart by differences can actually learn to like each other.

A wonderful story of how something which happened so, so long ago influenced the lives of young people - unbeknown you them. Loved the parallel story which provided a clever non-intrusive backstory to the Jellicoe Road community - townies, cadet and Jellicoe school.

Video review (as part of my November Wrap Up): https://youtu.be/4KfQycvLEHcI buddy read this with a lot of other Filipino bookworms and I'm thankful to have been able to join it because this is a book that's great for discussions.This book has an interesting and definitely different kind of arrangement from what I'm used to. It's got a very interesting first line which holds a lot of promise but the following chapters are very slow and can be confusing. The author also assumes that the readers are familiar with their local school system so it contributed to my confusion too. Now the biggest problem with this book is that it took around 150-200 pages until things really make any sense and a lot of people will understandably DNF this before getting to the turning point where the book lands an impact.
“My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die.I counted.
Whether the final pivotal chapters are worth all the build up pages is really dependent on if you're reading this with others or solo. This is definitely a good book for discussion but it's also the kind of book that's very polarizing. I think this line basically sums up what kind of experience this book will take you on:
"What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?"“When we get there, you’ll understand."
A Slowly burned novel. All worth it in the end. 😭😭😭

I'm so glad I continued reading it despite almost dnfing it at chapter 3. This is a beautiful book I would never forget. Writhed in pain as I read this, and found my pieces back. Truly remarkable, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!https://writtenbyal.wordpress.com/202...

The first few chapters were quite confusing, having to piece together what’s going on and trying to keep up with the events as well as the characters. It didn’t make much sense until after Ch 16 for me, because it felt like I just had so many questions about the setting and these kids and how the heck they’re living. After getting through the first few chapters though, I was captivated. The writing style is engrossing and the more you read it, the more you don’t want to put it down. The book got pretty heavy, which I didn’t expect! I loved how all the characters were intertwined and how the pieces slowly unraveled. It felt so messy but it was somehow woven together so well that everything just made sense in the end. This felt like a 3-star read in the beginning but after finishing it, this book deserves a 5. There were some parts that felt awkward but I loved it in its entirety. Definitely something that stays with you for a while after you finish reading it.
A very odd concept for a book, but once again the characters were all lovable, and the seamless switch between the past and the present was done flawlessly.

I loved this book. It has been on my shelves forever.The beginning started a little slow, like I was missing a 1st book or a couple early chapters. The flashbacks were also a bit confusing and to be honest even towards the end, I was confused by who some of the names were. But I did end up loving this one in the end....oh and don't we all want a little Jonah Griggs in our life?!
i don't think words can explain in words what i feel for these characters and their relationships so i am not even gonna try sorry just know that i love these characters with all my heart
This is the best book I have ever read. By far my absolute favourite.
One of the best books that I have read in school! I love the mystery and that you have to think for your self. You don’t get the answers right away. I also love all the twists in the book.
i can forgive how hard this book was to get into because in the end i loved it so much i was sobbing. found family excellence id say

If I hadn’t just read Chine, I would easily name this the best book I’ve read in grad school. At least I can name it the best contemporary YA. It will be a long time before Taylor Markham and her friends leave me ❤️
Still very firmly my favourite YA fiction. Strongly relatable, poignant and respectful of the adolescent condition. Love.

I think the beauty of this book lies in how harsh reality can be. It doesn’t use exaggerated language to describe tragic events. But it describes it in simple language like it is a fact of life until it roots in you deeply. That this is, indeed, life. A culmination of ugly and beautiful things that most often we don’t get to choose. We get dealt a lot and it depends on how we play the cards. The realization crept up on me slowly, until the story settled within my skin. I couldn’t read a book for a few days after because it was hard to get this story out of my mind. And that in itself is the mark of a five-star read.I love how effortlessly Marchetta weaves the tale of Fitz, Tate, Web, Narnie and Jude that took place so long in the past alongside Taylor’s own story and interspersing it with the tiny amusements of the Territory war that allowed friendships to grow between Taylor and the contemporaries from the other school. There are enough light moments to balance the dark ones out so that the book doesn’t become a total grief fest.Read the full review here - https://thezoyaproject.com/2017/12/21...

This book was certainly not bad and by the end I actually really liked where it ended up and had developed a fondness for pretty much all the characters by the time we got there. But the journey it took to get there was just so needlessly convoluted. I just felt the construction of this story didn't work for me. It's like it was doing everything possible to confuse me by constantly flitting between present and dreams and Hannah's story, but I don't feel like it actually added anything to the overall story by doing that. Like I still guessed all the revelations and it didn't make it more impactful by confusing me the entire time, I feel like if it was told in a less random time-jump way I could've felt these moments a lot more. There's these great emotional beats at the end that honestly didn't hit me the way I knew they should have because it took so long to get to it. Also the beginning plot of their 'house wars' or whatever was as dumb as it sounded and legit led nowhere. It felt like such ridiculous forced conflict and wasn't even well explained enough for me to care. It took itself far too seriously and I found myself eye-rolling for a lot of it and waiting for the real meat of the story to happen. I also found the main relationship and Taylor herself super grating. All of their decisions are beyond frustrating and I know they're teenagers and I know they need to grow in their arc, but I didn't really find myself routing for them for most of the book. By the end I enjoyed them enough separately that I was like, 'ok sure, fine' but again didn't hit me the way I felt it should've. Overall this book was just super weird. It's certainly different and I'm all for fresh ideas, but it just didn't do it for me at all. Not my fav, but I can see why others may have enjoyed it more.

This was my favorite book when I was 14. I ran to my library to get a copy after seeing a quote on Instagram. I had no idea that seeing that quote would lead me to my favorite book of all time! But since it was my favorite when I was just starting high school, I was scared that if I re-read it now that I’m older, it wouldn’t be my favorite anymore. I didn’t want the idealized version that I had in my head to leave, so I put off my re-read for years.Until I slipped into a reading slump and couldn’t stop thinking about it and found a beautiful new copy at a bookstore I only stumbled across and said “hey, this is fate.” And here I am at 2am clutching this masterpiece of a novel as close to my chest as possible wishing I could literally bury it physically into my heart because it was somehow so much better than the version I had in my head. I am cursing at myself for waiting so long to pick it up again and I am crying because I have too many feelings about this book.This will put you through it, okay? It will send you through such a spiral of emotions that in the end I promise you will be clutching it to your body just as I am right now and I promise that it will NEVER leave you. This is the only book I have ever read that I can just never stop thinking about.The characters are everything, the plot is everything, this book is EVERYTHING.It could be a little confusing in the beginning, but that’s only because you are trying to piece together Taylor’s life along with her. You feel every bit of emotion and confusion Taylor feels, and I think that is just the best kind of confusion.If I haven’t already convinced you, let me leave you with this: whenever I see this book in a store, I have a physical reaction. When I see it new, I literally almost cry and thank whatever god or force there is out there that the store even carries it and I clutch it and shake as I bring it up to the counter to buy it in a heartbeat. When I see it in a thrift store I have to just stand there in shock because I can’t imagine why anyone would get rid of it! And then of course I buy it even though I already have multiple copies because it is the book that makes me feel like it isn’t just a bundle of paper. I see a copy and I see something so beautiful, something that is almost alive, and I can’t bear to leave it behind.Read. This. Book.

One of the reviews for this book wrote "my throat has sealed up with emotion" and that is the most accurate description for what I am feeling right now. I am left sobbing and feeling raw and emotional. To me this is a book about trauma, healing, and loss, and I highly recommend it.

I love how Jude and Hannah are still in contact. I love how Taylor doesn't give up on her family. I love how her friends never leave her side. I love how strong the relationship between the original five were. I love how Raffaela and Chaz and Ben and Jessa and Chloe P. are there. I love that Jonah Griggs exists for Taylor. I love how deeply in love Tate was with Webb that it ruined her life. I love how it ruined Fitz's life too. I've read this book twice now. It still holds a special place in my heart. The author's writing style is just beautiful that it makes up for some of "over-used" tropes in this book. Yep, reading it for the second time in my quarter life definitely changes the way I love it now. There are some things that I used to love when I was younger that I do not now. However, those things are minor and they didn't change my mind and feeling toward this book. I still love it just the same. I didn't sob as hard as the first time I read this, now that I know what happens, but I still sob nontheless, just not as hard. This book is beautiful, inside and out.

This book was a little hard for me to get into at first because of all of the characters, but once I figured out who the characters were and what was going on, well, I LOVED it. It is a beautiful story and although it is very sad in parts, it is also heartwarming as well. This is a book I could read and re-read (I generally don’t re-read books because there are too many new books and too little time). But this one really touched me. Highly recommend.
It took me a minute to figure out what was happening in this story. It flips back and forth in time. There were some f words, otherwise I might have given it 5 stars
This may be the most depressing book I’ve ever read.

It took me days to finish this book. Why? Normally, a 290-page book takes me 3-5 hours to finish, but this book? Let's just say it needs a lot of time to digest. I've been meaning to read this book for ages but I always felt that I'm not ready for it...and up to this point (even after mincing it word by word), I still feel that I wasn't. Maybe I should've waited 'til I'm ready for this roller coaster ride. For those of you who loves a great drama unfolding right before you, then this is your book! Not giving out any details of the plot as it would be best to enter this hole blinded.

i mean, it was fine, i guess, there's some good lines, some complex relationships - i like the characters. i've been reading a lot of reviews in hopes of better understanding why people love this book so much, and all i've concluded is that i will never understand. a lot of the reasons people have for not enjoying this book are very dumb or downright factually incorrect. all of the five star reviews just gush about the story without mentioning WHAT or WHY they liked it.

This book was confusing and boring. None of the characters seemed right. The adults acted like children and the children acted like adults. The “twists” were predictable from the first few chapters and I didn’t enjoy the writing.

Looking for Alaska meets Picnic at Hanging Rock. An Australian school story that builds slowly and earns its character development, trusting the reader to get by without exposition. Australian accent warning on the audiobook (for those not cultured enough to appreciate it!).

I absolutely LOVED this book. I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I started it, but I found myself unable to put it down once I really got started. It is a bit heavy, and that makes me a little hesitant to suggest it to many people, but for those that can handle the drama, it's worth the read.I would love to see how a group of teenagers would react to the story. I'm in college, and I don't really relate to the issues and mindset that the characters are in. It would be interesting to see how the group would perceive different aspects of the story and in particular the major miscommunication about the turf war (if you've read it, you know what I'm talking about).WarningsDrugs: mentions of serious addiction and being highSex: pretty mild, a couple moments but not graphic at all, a few veiled jokesRock and roll: teenagers engaging in a turf war (meaning some verbal fights and related teenager behavior)Language: not too much, a handful of uses of a number of words (s and f are used most frequently but not obnoxiously)Violence: talk about suicide (quite a bit, can be disturbing for some), instances of teenagers fighting and hurting each other
3.5 stars

It is worth it, stick with itThis is lovely story that introduces intriguing characters amidst many twists and turns. Yes, the protagonist can be hard to like, and yes, the many characters can seem cluttered. However, it is incredibly satisfying in the end. 4 stars because the beginning could do a better job of grabbing the reader.

“My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die. I counted.”Talk about a HOOK.I had read some bright and shining reviews for this book and figured there was no way it could possibly live up to my expectations. But gratefully, it actually did. The whole story is linked together so beautifully and there are so many times when the writing itself is just beautiful, and I just really loved it.I will admit that I was pretty confused for the first chunk of this. Why do they have these territorial wars? Who are the cadets? I had to keep flipping back and forth to remember who in the flashbacks was related to who and who found who and how they were all connected, but honestly...it was worth it.
Ehh it was ok
Melina Marchetta's books unlock a new range of emotion in me.

"webb once said that a narnie smile was a revelation and, at this moment, i need a revelation. and i get one."reread after years (thanks to haivan ❤️) and i loved the story even more this time around, which i didn't think was possible. though the last 20 pages or so were a blur because of my tears, these characters and their story will always have a special place in my heart 🥺
A little slow and confusing in the beginning but everything comes together.
Minus one star because I was confused. A LOT. And I want to slap all the adults in this book. HARD. But wowza what an fantastic emotional rollercoaster.

It was a good book. I think I would have enjoyed it more if it weren't for the book discussions we did about this book in school. The teacher kind of gave it away early on and you had no space to form your own ideas about what would happen or how it all would turn out. There were some elements of surprise but mostly I think it was quite cliché and predictable. It was good, but not a challenging plot to figure out.
Teared up a lil reading this one in your honor @Jess Chen

Once again, Melina Machetta captivated me attention with this novel. At the age of 7, Taylor was abandoned by her mom at a 7-Eleven in Jellicoe. When she was 14, Taylor attempted to run away to Sydney to find her mom. But the boy she was with called for help, and her journey was cut short. Three years later, Taylor is now the head of her House at Jellicoe school, and she must take lead in the annual territory wars between the school, the Townies and the Cadets. But when Hannah, the closest thing Taylor has to a parent, Taylor starts down a path of discovery that will reveals a tragic history on the Jellicoe Road. One that she is a part of. I truly enjoyed reading this book. I enjoyed the territory wars between the three factions and how this year's leaders have entangled histories with each other. As this novel is told from Taylor's POV, it is interesting to see her view of things contrasted against the dialogue of other characters. There is a particular instance where we learn that despite Taylor's behavior, the girls in her house truly care about her. There book contains lessons on friendship, the pain and healing found in tragedy, and how a single life event can completely alter the course of ones life. The story has a few triggers. It mildly touches on drugs and the destruction they bring about, and there is one mention of child pedophilia. However, suicide plays a heavier hand in the book.Looking back on the book, I realize there are plenty of characters involved in the story that I wish we got to know a bit better. In the moment, I was caught up in Taylor's experiences, but I would have loved to know more about Jonah, Chaz and Rafaela's histories. Also, I got stuck for a moment between the epilogue and chapter 1. The book states there is a 22 year time gap, but when chapter 1 starts, Taylor is 17 years old. Took me a few minutes longer than it should have to think "Oh, Taylor must not be one of the people involved in the epilogue."Overall, a great read. This is the second work of Melina Marchetta I've read. I enjoy her writing style and stories, so I'll definitely be checking out her other works!

On the Jellicoe Road covers so much territory, so many issues and quite a lot of characters, but it is not overdone. I loved this book. It made me nostalgic of my childhood and reminded me of the 'gangs' we would form in my tiny primary school of just 40 kids, where each gang had a peppercorn tree as their base and there would be battles for territory and people. One gang even made a tunnel. So I found the main storyline and premise of the territory wars between the Jellicoe School, the cadets and the townies absolutely believable. Melina Marchetta can write such amazing and complex characters, and Taylor Markham is the perfect example. At times Taylor is all about Taylor, but she is also vulnerable and can bring people together. I don't even know what to write to do this book justice, there are so many good things in the mix. I was sad to finish the book and leave the characters behind (there were real tears), but I hope to return to them another time in the future. The audiobook reading by Rebecca Macauley was fabulous and I will seek out more of the books she has narrated.

3.5 – This was a book I wish I had the patience to read as an attentively challenged younger teenager. I couldn’t really appreciate much of what went on in the earlier chapters as a twenty-year-old but it’s the kind of storytelling that would have compelled me to write more nuance to my material at that age instead of going stagnant in my later teens.Marchetta offered little distinctions to set out a clearer picture of the grounds or the characters but I take it down as personal style and it’s not like it worked against her. The focus she set upon literary devices such as a Chekhov’s Gun was pronounced enough for younger readers to appreciate without making it unnecessarily complex. The text was haunting and wistful. It’s not the kind that would have made it difficult for me to put down but if I do, I’d somehow regret it because the story is littered with bits and pieces that are easily relevant to the plot later. I did get a little annoyed at some points when something is mentioned or introduced and the reader was expected to just take that in as it is despite how slightly important it is to remember it later in the story. It was a good piece. Yet I personally didn’t appreciate how the intentionally dispersed excerpts muddled the story in a way that hindered it rather than stylise or emphasise the plot.

This book is exactly the reason I cannot, to this day, figure out when to give up on a book and when to keep going. The beginning didn’t make sense to me. It felt like there were too many characters and too many stories being thrown at me all at once and I didn’t understand how they fit together. I was annoyed every time I picked it up, and wanted to put it down just as often. I was 180 pages in and at that point I felt if I stopped I would have wasted all that time I’d already spent on it. And it had such good reviews I had to wonder what I was missing. I wanted to know why people thought it was so good. So I kept going and it paid off. I had ALL the feelings when it was over. Such a lovely and heartbreaking story of love, loss, family and friendship. I’m so glad I did stick with it!

Bored me to death. Reviews said that it will get interesting and pieces would fit halfway or by 2/3 of the book but I just couldn’t wait. Can’t connect with the characters and story’s kind of confusing.
Re-reading a book you love feels like going home after a long time away. Melina Marchetta, you give me so many feelings.
why don’t i get to start territory wars with students from other schools
I thought I wouldn't enjoy re-reading this. I was wrong.

This has pretty much been on my reading list since it first came out in 2008. The original cover always intrigued me, and I'd see it everywhere at the library, book stores, and in my digital suggestions and recommendations. But then whenever I read the synopsis, I was always like, "Ehhhhh...."I have now finally read it!!!It was good. It was hard for me to get into at first. I had numerous false starts. But once I got going, I was fairly sucked in. I'm glad to have finally read it, but it won't be a book I'm revisiting any time soon.

I went through a lot of different feelings while reading this book; beginning with confusion. Once I thought I had a grip on what was going on I didn't really care but then I become consumed with needing to know what had happened in the past in.Too much teenage romance and angst for me but for lovers of YA I can imagine this being a real treat. It's beautifully written and draws you in.

this book was exceptional. fascinating, gripping, well-written, heartbreaking, beautiful- the english language needs more words to describe this one. i loved the characters, the plot, the way everything was revealed to us. be ready not to leave your bed for 7 hours once you open this book. i couldn’t recommend it highly enough.everyone has that one book or tv show or movie they wish they could erase from their memory and soak in again - this one is mine.
Amazing all the emotions

Super late to the game on this one, but it has got to be my new favorite book. I was confused at times until I got further along in the story but it was SO well written. I can already tell I’ll be reading it again and again that’s how much I love it. Also, Jonah Griggs has stolen my heart. Love his character. And Taylor Markham is one great character as well.

This is one of my favorite YA novels. I can't recommend it enough. I've read it multiple times, and each time I start again, I'm immediately pulled into Taylor's world. I always find something new, whether a character or a brief excerpt of prose, to fall in love with. Marchetta has a way of weaving a complex narrative together and making you swoon for Jonah Griggs in a way that will have this story sticking with you long after you read the last page.

Emo! Melodrama! Reviews for this book are very mixed, from "oh-my-gawd-I-loved-it!" to "omg-I-hated-it!". I can't say I hated it but I didn't like it. For about half of the book -I am lying, for the WHOLE book- I was 🤔 with the whole war game thing. What was the purpose of that game?? I thought I was reading a dystopian book... it didn't make any sense.Taylor, the MC, was either crying or being angry.. the whole book. Her love interest was another emo. Was there any happiness for those people? Hannah's story was MEH... only around the end we know who is who, so because it didn't interest me, when I was reading, Webb had the same face as Fitz and Jude, and Narnie and Tate were the same girl, so I had zero attach to these characters.Nope, i didn't like this book. Made me think the whole time "what is the point of this story?"

this was honestly the saddest book i've ever read in my life but so damn beautiful at the same time that it did something to me and now I'm broken and I'll need therapy for the rest of my life because I'll never be able to get over it

Reading through chapter 12 (page 140 out of 400), I was so utterly bored that I decided to give up, literally mid-sentence. And I don’t quit books easily. However, at 35% percent into the story, the writer should have provided a general overview, but this novel was entirely directionless. Without the blurb, I would not have had a clue what is going on. This scene threw me off: a panel of senior students from a boarding school discussing territorial rights with the leaders of the local school kids and a neighbouring military school. In fact, the council is about access to waterways - as if any of them had any actual claim to the land. This territorial dispute is never even properly explained. The novel seems to have two main characters. On the one hand, there is Taylor, now 17 [I will never understand the trend to upgrade occupations into female first names], who at 11 was abandoned by her mother at a petrol station, and at 14 tried to run away from said boarding school to find her mother. On the run, she somehow fraternized with Jonah, a "Cadet" and now her antagonist. However, this backstory is structured as one big secret with only morsels of information thrown in. Taylor is also a particularly mopey, unappealing character. Yawn. Then there is Hannah, a woman in her 30s who survived a car crash as a child. She lives on the school premises and is Taylor’s friend. Somehow she is a main character, even though she has been missing since page 1. Again, lots of mysterious hints. Apparently, at the end you find out how all the events and characters are connected to each other. But I obviously don’t care to find out. I don’t know why this book is so successful. It’s just so dull. So, goodbye.

Read this for the first time in 2014 and thought it was probably my favourite book so I was worried to reread it and it be not as good as in my memory but it was better!!!! Amazing, I love Melina Marchetta's writing - she gets no hype!!

The first third/half of this book took so much work to get through. It was so confusing!! I was finally able to just go with it and there ended up being a lot that I liked about it, but I don’t know if I can really say I loved it.
I found it hard to read at the start and considered giving up but I’m glad I persevered because I ended up really enjoying it.
Easily one of my all-time favorite contemporary books. I wish I could reset time and read it for the first time all over again.

NoveList Plus Info:Genre: Australian Fiction, Realistic FictionStoryline: Character-driven, Intricately plottedPace: Leisurely pacedTone: MelancholyWriting Style: Lyrical, Stylistically complex, Well-crafted dialogueSubject: Abandoned children, boarding schools, children of drug abusers, emotional problems of teenage girls, identity (psychology), Mother-separated teenage girls, schools, seventeen-year-old girls, teenage girls
I almost cried at the end.This book made me very emotional. It's just so unfair, what happened to these beautiful people in their lives.Too bad that the beginning was very confusing...
3.75 rounded up. It took me at least 100 pages to get into it, but I liked the way it ended

In the beginning I would have given this book a 2 star rating, I felt like I was starting to read a book in the middle... I found it confusing, but kept on reading, and was happy I did... everything came together, and it all made sense in the end! And what an ending 😊 just keep on reading!

A rollercoaster of emotions!I don’t have enough words to describe the astonishment that I felt towards Melina Marchetta’s masterpiece. Reading only the prologue got me hooked. The story is absolutely suspenseful and at the beginning you may feel a little lost until you understand what it’s about but as you go, pieces of the of story are revealed and with each one you’re at awe and can’t let go of the book anymore. As much as it was heartbreakingly tragic, I enjoyed the cynical humor that the characters possessed and I found myself laughing out loud so many times.“If something happens to me, whose face will be on the front page of the paper begging for me? Is a person worth more because they have someone to grieve for them?”

SO much drama crammed into one book, and the writing drove me crazy. I like a good mystery, but this was confusing for probably half the book and then suddenly made sense but in a bizarre way. No one talks to their kids about weird family histories? No teachers are around to help all these teens with serious issues? The ending is satisfying, but I toyed with giving up on the book until the last 100 pages.

Summary: Taylor was abandoned on the Jellicoe Road by her mother. Years later, she is the leader of the Jellicoe School students and is somewhat cynical due to the betrayals she has experienced throughout the years. However, she isn't the only one to face such hardships. Throughout the book, different characters face the struggles and trauma that burden them. As Taylor confronts her past, she learns more about love, friendship, and healing. Reaction: I love how the author expressed Taylor's thoughts and feelings. She is an interesting character, sharing some special quirks to which I can relate. For example, in the very first chapter, she mentions certain words that are perfect for describing her situation. That is such a small thing, but it caught my attention. Even though I appreciate her character, I am saddened by the experiences she faces in the novel. She and the other characters have some pretty serious trauma. It caused me to reflect on my own life and feel very grateful for my circumstances. Content Warnings: There are certain events such as murder, death, and suicidal thoughts. Domestic violence is also mentioned, along with side-effects of trauma, such as depression and anxiety. Some brief allusions to sexual activity. Mention of sexual assault.
Loved the story and the territory wars. I was very concused in the beginning and kept rereading the prologue at different times throughout the book.

^It is a bit confusing at first because its like a two stories, one in the past and one in the present, meshed in one but it is defined where one ends and one begins because the font style is different, but in terms of flow of text sometimes it is not easily distinguished and does not relate to each other but once you passed the first half of the books it gets more and more interesting so it requires a lot of patience. The wars is very simple but the resolution of the war is not executed well I think because it just suddenly dissolves over the holiday break and also SPOILERS!!! SPOILERS!!! it is a not so mind blowing that the wars is just an invented game. HERE IS WHAT I LOVE, I love that all that story in the first half slowly interweaves and make sense onto the second half of the book. That is if you remember the deets in the first half. More revelations coming in which I will not spoil thats just heart warming and endearing. It is like a puzzle that you have to figure out piece by piece in order to fit. I was definitely able to predict who is who and which is which. The pace is engaging on the second half but the first half is so-so. I wish I have seen more about Tate perspective or at least a background of it. Overall I enjoyed reading it despite the trecherous first half.I HAVE TO BE HONEST this is not a wow book for me. I mean it was okay, but not the same reaction that the majority has...I get tripped off and put off by the switching of persepctive sometime. There are times I have to go back to tell who was talking. And sometimes I could not take the insensitiveness of Taylor even though she has a very tragic past and maybe a rough childhood I will not be able to justify her rudeness with those. I mean come on she supposed to be a leader right! But I felt like there are parts that she is so self centered. Yes I get that Hannah is missing and she's her rock but blowing off Jessa or Chloe like that is just I hate her in thoseI HAVE TO TALK ABOUT JONAH. I wish there were more back stories about him. I really want to know what happen between him and his father. Also I wanna know why he wanted to do what he wants to do in that train station where he met Taylor.TOWNIES, CADETS AND THE REST OF THE PLOTI wish that there are more deets about the war, how did the townies had the claim for the prayer tree and why Taylor and the Jellicoe school lost it last year. I wish they have made known that the war was an invented game not just made a party which forces all three groups to mibgke which other with no explanation whatsoever except that fact that Taylor and Jonah pashed. I hope more background on Rafaella and Santangelo to tell who they really are personally. Also again to Tate, I hope they have met properly.I know I am part of the few, but I'll tty to reread it and see if my view chabe because the book has BEAUTIFUL WRITING you can really feel the HEAVINESS OF THE EMOTIONS CLINGING ONTO THE WORDS.

It took a few chapters to feel part of this story, which I believe was intentional - the characters would want you to be on the outside looking in for a little bit. I couldn't put it down after those first few chapters though, I was part of the Jellicoe Road war games.The idea that a bunch of teenagers would wage a war around the town for the holidays was fun and gave the whole book a purpose that was always there.I loved the idea of this story, and I thought the author did an amazing job of describing the area - the school, town and cadet camp. I could see all the boundaries, and I could feel the summer air. I loved that this story was set in a country town of Australia, but it didn't have the usual dry Australian language to describe it - that was almost my favourite part. The characters, wow. Every character had depth, a story, a part to play. Marchetta captured everything about being seventeen and having seen/lived trauma, and it was brilliant.I thoroughly enjoyed every moment of this book (after the first few jarring chapters).

I learned so much reading this. I've completely immersed myself the characters' incredibly realistic lives, facing horrors that they have been forced to behold. The psychological depth of the characters is insanely complex, which is probably the highlight of this book. Living in the heart of Sydney rather than the rural setting of Jellicoe Road, I don't think I ever understood how different the culture is there, and how people living in those areas see Sydney in such a different light. It was especially jarring to see familiar suburbs and australian jargon mentioned, especially since I had NO idea that this book was in any way australian. I have no idea how non-australian readers would get every single reference, like the school level system eg. "year eleven" or the popular TV show Home and Away. On a kind of unrelated note, Kings Cross is MUCH safer today, which is why I was so shocked at the description the book gave.I still have to say, the plot was very confusing even to the end, and the construction of the plot had little logical sense, even if it moved character arcs forward and clues into light. For example, the warring tribe system between the Cadets, Townies and the Houses absurdly seemed to be taken too seriously one moment and then the rules were very quickly ignored the next. There was a lack of motive and reason why characters chose to do certain things, like breaking into the Brigadier's tent and having a party at the Club House. These could almost be plot holes, but I'm willing to put them away as devices to make the story more efficient.Overall I'm rather conflicted on how to rate this. I'll leave it at 3.5 for now I guess?
This was a good book, though I would recommend reading carefully. I had to keep a list of who was who and their names and nicknames and relationships
One of the best books i’ve ever read, i really liked the writing and the story! READ IT

Wow! What an intense book! Taylor Markham has dealt with and lived with a lot in her 17 years, including being abandoned by her mother when she was 11. I liked almost everything about this book except two side plots (view spoiler)[the pedophile she didn’t remember until she met the former neighbor kid whose mother left him with the pedophile for 2 weeks and the serial killer who was casually revealed at the end of the book.(view spoiler)[ (hide spoiler)] (hide spoiler)]
I don't know if it's because of the audiobook but the book felt a bit flat for me. It was dragging and confusing.

Reasons why I gave it three stars - the writing style. I think it was really beautiful and lyrical and was what kept me reading. I finished the whole book in one sitting - the boy in the tree. oh man the feels, loved this supernatural/spiritual element of the novel and it all ties up neatly at the end-the humour. Reasons why I didn’t give it more stars-predictable plot. I guess this must have been from my years of experience of reading Agatha Christie novels, because I made connections quite early and like one of the reviews I read about this book it was more of a waiting game.-confusing nature of the beginning. I think many people had this problem too and I guess it’s part of the whole setup of the book. But I think the whole subplot with the territorial wars was kinda unnecessary and boring. -romance. I think I’m in the minority here. I didnt really care much about Griggs. I kinda found their relationship boring and a bit cringe to read honestly. But then again, I’ve read quite a lot of ya and nearly all of them have romance in them.Overall I think if I read this book younger it would probably have a more heavier impact on me emotionally.

The first half of this book was confusing. I'm not gonna lie. But one you reach the middle and everything starts making sense it's so worth it! I'm so glad I finally decided to pick this book up after having it on my tbr for at least 6 years.
What a strange little book. I didn't know where this was going for a good while but I ended up invested in the characters by the end.

I finished this and immediately wanted to read it again, to put the clues together, piece out the story, and really just experience this one more time in all its heart wrenching glory. This is so much MORE than what the cover makes it out to be. I thought this was simple romantic contemporary but I was wrong!! It has mystery and secrets and violence and tragedy and pain and suffering and love and loneliness it has.....everything. I loved this so much. I cried..so..much. I thought I had gotten to the point where I no longer wanted to read YA and was really thinking about donating this book because it just didn’t seem “my style” anymore. So uhh note to self: don’t cancel YA just because you feel like you’re too old or too good for it. That Printz award was given for a REASON. Please read this
A book i will always go back too. Makes me laugh, cry and think, all in the blink of an eye.

I... don't know how to rate this book? Reading this felt like I was in a dream, in the sense that I'd watch everything happen and even when things didn't make sense (read: the entire first half of the book) I would not question them, almost like in a haze. Even though Jellicoe Road didn't deeply touch my heart the way it did to many people, I have to say Melina Marchetta's writing is beautiful, and this dream-like mood which persists throughout the entire book was created solely through her amazing way with words. As some have already said, this book isn't for everyone - and I'm not sure it was for me. I still need to give it a few days but I believe I was more fascinated by the writing and the mood of the story rather than by the story itself.
Emotional roller coaster - tragedy, romance, mystery. I enjoyed it.

OH GOD. after 6 years since i bought this book, i've finally gathered up the energy and courage to read it. i read this on a rainy afternoon, sitting in my living room and crying by the end of it. this is such a beautiful story about love, family, and how we deal with our past. the story revolves around taylor markham, a student in a school for neglected children, who's been assigned as the leader for the upcoming territorial wars in the area. (i promise you this isn't the whole plot and also it gets really confusing at the beginning.) hannah, her guardian/mentor, disappears and it sends taylor looking for clues to find her, which leads to taylor uncovering her past. all of that heaviness occurs in the midst of teenage shenanigans so it's the perfect blend of light and heavy. i liked this book. it took a while for me to vibe with it because the whole territorial wars did not make sense to me at all and quite frankly, i don't really know if it makes sense to the characters either. if you can't get past that, then i don't think the whole story is for you. in any case, i resolved to finish this book so i forced myself to get through it—which turned out to be not such a chore as marchetta's writing is easy to read and the characters and the hints at their relationships are fun. there's also the matter of shifting POVs through flashbacks, but the flashbacks are in italics so it's easy to distinguish. the whole kids in love during the summer was great and fun, but it blindsides you and leaves you vulnerable for what's to come. because when it gets to around the 250-ish page mark, that's when you know that shit is about to go down. and go down it did because the story gave me such complete heartache. i'm completely torn apart by the events at the end. the characters were great although i didn't really connect with them, i was definitely attached. i liked how the taylor/jonah/raffy/chaz friendship was written and i cried even more over "what are you so sad about? we're going to know him for the rest of our lives." honestly, out of the original five, jude was a surprise character for me because it hurts to think about him. he's kind of the outsider of the group, longing to be a part of it but when he does, it's under the most terrible circumstances. this book was by no means perfect. as i said, the beginning was a little difficult to get into. i may be in the minority but i didn't really care about the romance—i understand that the author draws parallels between taylor/jonah and both webb/tate and narnie/jude but uh it's not for me. they had a good enemies to lovers thing going on and a shared past but they were just okay if not a little too intense for me. it also had two sex scenes that the book could have gone without. minor things in the midst of how much the story touched me. overall, this was a good read and if you're in the mood to cry and read about deep and life-changing friendships then this is the book for you. (content warnings: pedophilia (minor mention), character death, physical abuse from parent, forced prostitution (non-MC), drug use/abuse)

I was almost in tears by the time I finished this book. On The Jellicoe Road is about so many things, but at its heart it's about memory, trauma, learning to forget, and having to remember again. It's the least condescending book I have ever read - there's no all-knowing narrative voice that's telling us what's going on. Instead we try to piece things together just as Taylor does, through fragments of her childhood memories, dreams, and extracts from an unfinished book found in an unfinished house. But this book is also about other things I love to see in contemporary fiction for teens. Friendship and romance and how kids & teens find their chosen families and do everything they can to care for each other. And then there's the territory wars - this book recognizes that kids and teens have their own games, economies, traditions, and histories. I loved everything about this book. I read it over six weeks and incidentally, that's how long the plot is paced over too! I would recommend it to people, yes, but there are trigger warnings: drug abuse, mention of child abuse, mention of self-harm.
Great Book!
It was decent, but I was burnt out on books and DNFed at 50%. Not the book's fault at all. I seriously enjoyed Looking for Alibrandi.

This book had so much potential, but the plot was not executed well. First of all, it was too confusing! I read the book in a matter of a few days but still found myself struggling to figure out what was going on in the book...and that is NOT typical for me because I easily recall details. My other major complaint was the current day territory wars. It took up too many pages of the book and was taken to the extreme. I wish more time had been dedicated to developing the characters instead. Overall, the pace was okay and the storyline was an awesome idea but it just wasn’t connected well enough. I knew what I should have been feeling at the end of the book but I wasn’t affected because the characters hadn’t been developed enough. I doubt I will read more by this author.

4 stars. One of the best YA novels I've read, but a bit overly-emotional (dramatic) and maudlin. The utter lack of proper communication amongst characters drove me crazy too. Yes, sometimes people don't communicate well, but generally if you have been taking care of someone (de facto parenting) you wouldn't just disappear for weeks with the entire rest of the adults in the town in a conspiracy with them to not tell you where they are or what happened to them - particularly if they have been your only guardian! Aside from those two gripes, it was well written with a lot of depth to the characters and storyline.

this is the kind of book that feels like a warm blanket, only one that makes you want to cry, punch a wall, and recommend it to everyone you know. i don't know how to phrase any review of jellicoe road in a way that's not incredibly cheesy. I just know I'll be chasing books that make me feel the way this one does for the rest of my life.

Quite confusing at first, with the different set of characters and plot placed at the beginning which was explained later in a few chapters. It took me awhile to understand the territory wars, the five characters at the beginning. It just seemed like a lot was happening. But it was a good read. It had me crying at some parts.

This is the type of book that sticks with you for a lifetime. Once again, Melina Marchetta has achieved something I can only assume all great authors strive to accomplish: move readers in a ways so profound that’s its sometimes inexplicable. Because words fails and the only thing you’re left to do is simply feel. Feel for the beautifully tragic and lost characters that you’ve been introduced to. To read this novel is to fall in love. To read this novel is to root for, yearn for, mourn over, laugh with, be angry at, and cry over a handful of complex characters that life has broken, damaged, and torn apart. To read this book is to find characters you may see bits and pieces of yourself in, characters harbouring uninvited, painful memories of the past that sneak back up on them in terrible ways and force confrontation. But it’s also about the beautiful memories. The memories of love from the past that keep you holding on, fighting, to see the future. This story absolutely broke me. But it also taught me about the power of friendship and hope; how when you’re lost, you can find a home in the people you love. And I know for a fact, it’s a story I’ll find myself revisiting time and time again.

I completely loved this book! Despite the tragic backdrop to the story, it still feels so beautiful and uplifting to read. At first I was extremely confused with exactly what was going on, but once I learned that the territory wars are just a game, the book became a lot more easier to read. The book is about a girl named Taylor Markham whose drug-addicted mom left her with Hannah, her caretaker for the meantime. It follows her journey as she uncovers more about her past and takes part, alongside her friends, in these “territory wars” between the Cadets and the Townies. This book is very unique to me, and its style is different from anything else I’ve read. The story deals with such dark themes, yet Taylor takes these made-up territory wars with her friends very seriously. To me, it added this imaginative and whimsical nature to the book which almost felt out of place since the story gets so dark. Also, although the book was very confusing in the beginning, I actually came to appreciate that because it makes us empathize more with Taylor who’s also left in the dark with her own past.
Finished my 3rd reread on 1/4/21 Starting off the new year by rereading Jellicoe Road and it hurts so bad.
Definitely one of the best YA I encountered!
This book has heart and soul and is beautifully crafted. My best read of the year so far. Full review to follow.

The mix of fantasy and fiction is so well intertwined that it envelopes you into the world that Melina Marchetta is creating. The characters are unique, independent and intriguing. I felt connected to Taylor from the minute I started reading. I wanted to live out her ambitions, empathize with her hurt and pain and experience her freedom. The concept of the story is simple yet complex in that it covers the intricate details of the lives surrounding the Jellicoe Road. This book moved me. I cannot explain the impact that this coming of age novel has had on my own coming of age. This is one of those gems that you find at a travelling book store. A tale as old as time.

One of my all-time favorite books! I started to read this one several years ago but couldn't get past the first 2o pages. Several years later I tried to read it again and once again couldn't read more than 20 pages before I put it down. So, several years later, after a friend read it and loved it I decided to try one more time. This time I got past the first 20 pages and was blown away. It was more than I ever thought it would be and had such an unexpected depth that made it so much more than what those first 20 pages could ever have prepared me for. I was so surprised and so happy that I read it again because it is one of the best books I have ever read.

Jellicoe Road started off slow for me. I wasn't sure where the story was heading or really what was going on. It felt like I was missing something, like a book or a story that preceded the one I was reading, but that confusion didn't last very long because I was hooked and I knew the answers would reveal themselves in time.I am blown away by how beautiful and poignant this story is. It's my second Melina Marchetta novel and definitely my favorite. I can't believe I waited so long to read it or how I even fleeting thought this might be a DNF. The writing is beautiful and so is the story.
One of those rare books, that pulls you into the story from the first page. Tears are falling, but no way to stop reading.

Okay, D., you were right and Marchetta is a really good writer and this book was sweet and well-done and very much what I like out of my realistic fiction. The mystery was handled well and, even though there were elements that I figured out, there was no sense that the characters ought to have had the distance or knowledge to do so. And the story itself and the people was really good!

I'm not exactly sure how I feel about this book. It was pretty confusing at first trying to figure out who all the characters were. But I also didn't want to stop reading. It was predictable and dramatic, but also showed some character development. There is some language in it so I'm not recommending it to my kids.
06/09/13  No real review I remember this being one of my favorites will definitely need to read again.

It's kinda confusing at first but slowly you start to know these characters and then you fall in love with them. I can totally understand who so many people recommend this book, it's a beautiful story of friendship, love and loss.

4.50 🏠This story is so tragic it breaks my heart in a million pieces. Is the kind of book you get a book-hangover for a week. It has left me with a sense of inmense longing and another of belinging to a past and a story that I was never part of- This story made me feel as if I belonged there with the characters, with Taylor, Jonah, Narnie, Webb, Jude, Chaz and Raffy..... Melina Marchetta has this talent of creating characters that become alive of the page, characters that could easily be real, so full-fledged and raw. Sometimes I felt I was reading a something that truly happened, and that if I wanted I could meet the characters.The story was so beatiful, full of everything I wanted and more.I have to be honest, I didn't adored as much as Saving Francesca, but that is only due to the fact that I connected on more a personal level to the main character in that book. Still, this one is still pretty awesome! I love how you can see the development of the author in her novels, fills me with a sense of freshness everytime I read her work.
"But that night, on the Jellicoe Road, it was like he was reborn."

I have been amazed with this story of love, friendship, tragedies and families, I fell too much in love with the characters and at the end I became so fond of them that I do not want to let them go ... I bought this book 3 years ago from a warehouse sale and just picked it up recently to read during this Enhanced community quarantine. At first, i was confused and bored while reading the first few pages. I thought it was the usual teen romance/drama novel and thought of putting it back on my shelf and choosing another book to read, but I ended up giving this book a chance. I was gripped by the story and there came a time when i cannot put it down(except when i needed to do some chores). I was so hooked. And felt like i was there with Taylor (the protagonist) holding her hand while she unravels the mysteries and secrets of her past(and the people in it) to have a better or clear understanding of who she is. Words are not enough to describe how beautiful this book is. I fell deeply inlove with the characters(I shed tears for some). This is a masterpiece and i think it's underrated and if there's a book that everyone should be talking about i think this should be it. I think i won't get over this book anytime soon. How can i move on from this one?!! It's so heartbreakingly beautiful. A must read!!!! pYou might not like it at first but be PATIENT WITH IT. i'm telling you... IT'S ALL WORTH IT.
love anything Melina writes. I always hanging out for the next one. Page turning, insightful full of heart

I. Love. This. Book.This book reminds me why I love Melina Marchetta's writing so much ( and that I need to buy her 2 new books!).This book has everything! aww this one to make ur heart sad and happy all at once. The build up was necessary but longThis book is enchanting. I loved it.

“A home to come back to every day of their lives. Where they could all belong or long to be. A place on the Jellicoe Road.”I’ve wanted to read this ever since I spotted it in my social studies teacher’s library in 6th grade. When I found it years later on Goodreads, even just reading the summary gave me feelings I’ve lacked in, but yearned for for so long. But I never got around to reading it until now, and I’m thankful for that. It’s like I somehow knew I’d read this book at the exact right time in my life. I’m an *incredibly* picky reader, and it takes a lot for me to really love a book. To connect with every character in their own way. To read about themes and messages I need desperately to learn myself. To feel part of the story. To even happen to like the same music the characters reference. But for the first time in around 5 years, a book - this book, of course - did all that and more for me. Thank you, Melina Marchetta, for writing an absolute freaking masterpiece.

The students at Jellicoe School have 2 groups of enemies: the Cadets and the Townies. This three-way rivalry has resulted in the Territory Wars, in which each set of teens elects leaders, holds negotiations, takes hostages and patrols its borders. One night, some year seven students from the dorm led by Taylor Markham stray into Cadet territory. The girls are captured and held hostage. Taylor and other Jellicoe School leaders hike through the Australia bush to reach the Cadet camp, where Taylor comes face-to-face with Jonah Griggs. Taylor Markham was abandoned at the boarding school when she was 11, and she tries not to think too much about her troubling past. But the summer of her 17th year brings it all back. The very people whom she might look to for help are the same ones who are stirring the pot:	Hannah the dorm supervisor who has always been like a second mother (but not quite); Jonah Griggs, a boy with whom she tried to run away (but is now leader of the enemy Cadets);	and Chaz Santangelo, son of the town police chief who seems to know more about Taylor's past than she does. Taylor has the same dream again and again: Read p. 4 "Somewhere in the hazy world … I blame the Cadet for that." Winner of the 2009 Printz Award for the Best YA Fiction
I love this book with every piece of my heart ❤️❤️🥺
ONE OF THE BEST BOOKS EVER WRITTEN!! I really really loved this book. Everyone should read it. It made me laugh, it ,ade me cry, it made my heart ache.

This is definitely Marchetta's most sophisticated effort and is quite a heavy issues-based young adult text. Nevertheless, I felt some parts were rather haphazardly thrown together and the whole thing was a bit melodramatic for my tastes.
Check on US publication date?

At First Sight: For the last six years, Taylor Markham has lived on the Jellicoe School, under the care of a woman named Hannah who picked her up after her mother abandoned her at a Seven-Eleven. Taylor has always been full of questions: about her mother's whereabouts and about her father, and about what role Hannah plays into it all.But now she's seventeen, as far away from answers as ever, and with the responsibility of leading the boarders in the territory wars between them and the cadets and the townies. And then Hannah leaves under mysterious circumstances, leaving behind a bad tempered cat and a manuscript telling the story of five kids who lived on the Jellicoe Road some twenty years before.Without Hannah, Taylor is more lost than ever, and the fact that Jonah Griggs is back doesn't help matters at all. Second Glance: I've read Jellicoe Road before, I even reviewed it once before. But this time I decided to listen to the Audiobook of it when I came across the australian edition - something I hadn't done before - and while the story remained the same, it was a very different experience. I liked hearing the voices of Taylor, Jonah, Chaz and Raffy, and everyone else, I thought the narrator - Rebecca Macauley - did a good job of it, making different voices for everyone and her guy-voices were pretty good. Also, I noticed stuff about the characters that I hadn't before, like that Taylor was a bit of a Drama Queen, something that I had never noticed before. On the down side, the musical transitions between chapters and between past and present were too long and they got kind of annoying after a while. Bottom Line: Jellicoe Road remains one of my favorite books ever and I liked the Audiobook, but I still think I like the reading experience a bit better.

Cross posted from my 
blog review
.This is one of those books that 1) you should go into not knowing much of anything, 2) that will probably leave you very confused for the first 100 pages or so, but 3) is ultimately one you’ll end up loving, or at the very least appreciating the cleverness behind the structure. Preferably you’ll have read one of Melina’s other books before (and if we’re speaking of “preferably,” that book will have been Looking for Alibrandi, because I think it’s better than Saving Francesca), so you’ll know Melina’s a fine writer who knows what she’s doing and isn’t just getting sloppy.It’s hard to say what Jellicoe Road is about exactly—I don’t want your reading experience to be ruined. And anyway, even if I did tell you what it’s about, this novel has so many facets, it’s hard to give a full picture without making you sit down and read it. It’s a mystery novel about finding yourself; it’s a family story about a girl who is, for all intents and purposes, an orphan; it’s a story about friendship for a girl who always thought she was alone; and it’s about a road that, immobile as it is, is constantly changing to the eye of each beholder. It’s no wonder this novel is so confusing at first—it’s a paradox of itself.Anyway, as I was saying in the beginning, this book’s different, in structure as much as plot. There are two main storylines, one from the past—seventeen years before—and one in the present. The Past one tells the story of five teenagers who were friends, family, and couples, all of whom had special ties to the Jellicoe Road. The Present one tells the story of one lone teenage girl who’s been abandoned by her mother, who’s got no recollection of her father, and who has no other family to speak of. The Present is told in real time through Taylor’s first person narration; the Past is told through manuscript pages written by a woman who’s been like a mother—but not really a mother—to Taylor ever since she was abandoned. The book basically keeps going with each storyline until both merge and you see how they’re connected.Like I said: this isn’t a book I’ve—or you’ve, I’d wager—read before. It’s original and elusive, and, when all is said and done, brilliant.
