It kept me at bay, grasping for clues where there just weren’t any until everything made sense in a way I wouldn’t have guessed.I’d like to say there’s a bit in here for everyone. You’ve got your romance, your twisting-and-turning plot, your poetic prose, your instant solid characters, and your underlying passionate and solid storytelling.Possibly on my list of favorite YA books ever, probably my favorite Melina Marchetta, and definitely on my top ten for this year (US release date, of course). Shoo-in for an A.

I absolutely loved this book. I wont lie, it does take about the first 30 or so pages to get into it, and I was also a little confused because there are really two stories going on that connect everything in the end, but once I figured out what was what, I loved it! I relly liked the characters also. There were so many qualities to love about Taylor and her friends in this story. While I read the ARC, Im sure anyone who picks up the published edition will love this story too. It has a lot about family, friendship, love, growing up, letting go and holding on-at the same time, sadness and joy with a lot of laughs in between. Also, I love that there is a little bit of mystery to it!

Taylor Markam was abandoned by her mother at a 7-Eleven on Jellicoe Road when she was a mere eleven years old. Only moments later a woman by the name of Hannah picked her up and brought her to the Jellicoe School. Now she is seventeen and finds that Hannah is a rock in her inconsistent life. While she has Hannah, Taylor doesn't know much about her family except the horror stories she remembers of her mother. She does find comfort though in a manuscript that Hannah has written about a group of five friends who met in the worst circumstances, but delved a remarkable friendship when they only had each other. When Hannah just up and leaves, Taylor doesn't understand what has happened and she becomes a wreck. Not only does she have to deal with Hannah's disappearance, but she has just been named the head of her House and the leader of the school kids in the annual territory wars against the "Townies" and "Cadets." In the war the three groups battle and negotiate following an extensive set of rules that might as well be history. As the war wages on Taylor learns to take an active role in her community as well as develop relationships that she never thought possible. Especially with Jonah Griggs, the leader of the Cadets whom she already has quite a history with already. This war will be like no other. It will not only be between the normal three parties, but among friends, hearts desires, and most of all Taylor herself.From the title I was expecting a light and fun read. Wow, was I wrong. This book is filled with heartbreak, joy, laughter and sorrow. It completely blew me away and surpassed every expectation I had, even though I was expecting something completely different. Before I even get into the elements of the story I have to comment on how much talent the author has. Melina Marhetta's writing style is indescribable. It seemed that she was so comfortable writing the story and her words just flowed from page to page with great clarity. I loved how the author weaved many intricate details and mini-stories into one big story, making it like a puzzle that slowly comes together until those last couple of pieces which just fall into place. The only miff I had with this book is that it took me probably until the third chapter to actually understand what was going on. In the beginning there were two stories going on and it was hard to wrap my head around everything that was happening. After that though it seemed the author settled into writing and the story took off. Taylor without a doubt is one of the best characters that I think has ever been created. She has this true voice where you can hear and feel her emotion ring out. By the time the book had ended I felt like I knew Taylor like I know my best friends. While Taylor was the main character, the author did a fabulous job creating the other characters. Unlike many supporting characters, the characters in Jellicoe Road all had their own voices and became their own person with a real and likable personality. I highly recommend this book to readers everywhere. Whether you're a girl or a guy, you will treasure this novel and hold it near and dear to your heart for a long time to come. Jellicoe Road is a beautiful love story, a heart wrenching story of loss, a poignant self-discovery, and most of all an unforgettable tale. It is by far one of the best books of the year.

I got this book as an ARC through HarperCollins and I loved it! I'm a fan of the other two books by Melina Marchetta and I was so excited to get this in the mail! I had a hard time getting into it in the beginning because there is so much information about people, places, and events without enough information to understand what was going on and it was probably 60 pages before I really started to like it. It's different from Marchetta's other books. And there are also two stories going on at the same time so working that out took a few chapters. It's a sad book, yet at the same time so readable and enjoyable. Marchetta is extremely talented at creating likable characters. I actually read it twice in four days. There is swearing and I didn't like how the two main characters had sex. I thought it would've been more 'romantic' if they had just held each other.
Slow to start, but a beautiful story.

Complicated, moving, beautiful, great. With just two chapters left to go I carried this book around with me for a week before I finally forced myself to finish reading it and move on already. I simply didn't want this book to end!

I stand corrected. This one was wonderful once I got through it. Now I need to go back and read the whole thing again now that I know how it's all tied together. Marchetta still rocks! I'm not sure how many teens will get through this, but I have a newfound respect for the Printz committee. :-)OK - I'm trying this one again - moving it back up from my "Could Not Finish" list. A friend who helped select it for the Printz award said that the ARC had tons of errors. So now I have the real thing. We'll see if it's any better this time around....Oh man - I LOVED Marchetta's "Saving Francesca", so when I saw her newest at ALA I grabbed the ARC. But I'm so disappointed to say that I couldn't get through it... It's a very odd story about Taylor, a girl who lives at a boarding school since being abandoned by her mother at age 11. Each fall, the students at the school engage in a "war" with the townies and a group of cadets that come to camp in the woods near the school. Each team has their own territory, and there are constant skirmishes between the groups. Taylor is appointed the leader of her group, so the book is divided into a plotline about the battle, but interspersed with stuff about Taylor's past life and the mystery behind her mom's disappearance. It's very confusing. Lots of typos in the ARC too, which made it even harder to read. I tried for 100 pages, but had other better stuff calling me. Oh well.
Was harder to get into for me than her other books, but I was very moved by the end. She is a great storyteller.

This book - whoa. I could have read it in one setting if not for mid-terms coming up and all. At first, it may be hard to understand exactly what's going on, but what's so amazing is that you really won't care. You'll be caught up in the writing (which is incredible) and the characters (all of whom are compelling and sometimes funny and sometimes heartbreaking). You'll keep reading just because you can't stop. Then you'll start putting together the pieces and understanding some things and having eureka moments at random intervals. This book is so great, it immediately made it's way to my favorites. Romantic and tragic and a whirlwind of a novel, you NEED to read this one.
Could not get into it at all. And then I got another, more interesting book.

I adored this book - putting together the puzzle and the relationships and how everything, absolutely everything was connected. So great. Sad, but so great. My YA for Adults book club weren't such big fans of it though. Makes me want to go read all of Marchetta's books.Bookalicious selection December 2014.
Brilliant and well-deserved winner of the 2009 Printz award.
As others have said, this one was a bit slow-going and confusing at first, but once it all started coming together it was an affecting story.

I don't think she is well-known overseas but Melina Marchetta has a great reputation as an author of young adult fiction (and now fantasy) in Australia. She wrote a very popular book called Looking for Alibrandi which is studied by most high school students. Marchetta has a gift for exploring themes relevant to teenagers and this is shown in another of her novels, Saving Francesca, and now On the Jellicoe Road as well.On the Jellicoe Road is about the life of a young girl named Taylor who is abandoned by her mother on the Jellicoe Road and becomes resident of a nearby boarding school. She develops a close relationship with the woman who found her, Hannah, but when Hannah disappears, Taylor's world starts to crumble, and she realises she must find out what happened to her own mother.The plot actually goes much deeper than what I've described, and for the first half of the book, it's rather a confusing process trying to follow the characters (there is a separate story running throughout and it takes a while to get the gist of what's going on). However, the reader who sticks with it will be rewarded for their efforts, for when all the dots are joined at the end, it is just beautiful (have some tissues handy). I cannot recommend this highly enough; it's really a unique and lovely read.
So far a little fractured, but I've heard that it all comes together in the ending...I'll keep you all updated!

I've liked Marchetta's other books, but I do not understand the acclaim surrounding this one. When you hear other librarians saying that it took them over a hundred pages to get into the story, how can you expect teens to read it? I made it to page fifty before I gave up, and this is the Printz title that convinced me there's no point in continuing to do Printz displays--how can I talk teens into reading books I can't even read?
reread: 24 Dec 2016
By far my favorite book of 2008. Intergenerational tale of 10 teenagers all of whom live at one time or another along Jellicoe Road.

ONE OF THE BEST BOOKS I HAVE EVER READ. Malina Marchetta draws you into a spellbinding story of a girl who finds herself through the history of five friends who spent their days by the river, in trees, dreaming up games like the territory wars. Now taken seriously, the territory wars between the Cadets, Townies, and Jellicoe School are just one problem Taylor Markham is faced with as leader. Taylor also has to deal with Jonah Griggs, a cadet she ran away with in year seven, who betrayed her. Now he is the leader of the Cadets and anger from the past resurfaces as well as feelings neither of them can explain. On Jellicoe road you find the importance of friendship, the gutt-wrenching loss of family, and the ever present element of love. Even though it is very confusing in the beginning, the mystery and possibilities of what might happen draw you to Taylor and her problems. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this books for a novel that with blow your mind and make you rethink the roads we take in life. Jellicoe Road was brilliant.
I love the way Melina Marchetta writes. Twisty, confusing, understated, and everything comes together in the end. One of those books you have to read twice.

Melina Marchetta at her best. Though technically a YA novel, this book is highly enjoyable for adults as well. About friendship and self-discovery, featuring a smart heroine with the right amount of sass.

I really really love this book, it is my favourite melina marchetta book, and its just a wonderful book, i couldnt put it down. although it is a little bit slow in the very beginning but it picks up and its awesome.

I bought this book as soon as it came out because I was expecting another 'Looking for Alibrandi' or 'Saving Francesca', which it definitely isn't. Melina Marchetta evidently decided when writing this to branch out and try some new things, which is great, but I didn't like the book and felt BETRAYED that she'd made that decision just when I'd decided I had enough faith in her to buy her books without reading them first. I found the whole ultra-mysterious 'brooding' tone pretentious and the romance between the characters was too melodramatic for my taste. Although I'm sure it will ring true for adolescent girls everywhere who will no doubt be all 'OMG I can totally relate to Taylor because she is like, so INTENSE and has had so much EMOTIONAL TRAUMA in her life, just like ME!'Besides that, though, I thought the mystery part of it was poorly done. A lot of people are saying in their reviews that they found it 'confusing', at least at first - and it is. There's a fine line between giving everything away and not revealing anything at all until the very end. When done correctly the reader is left guessing, but not frustrated. This, in my opinion, did not get the right balance.

Prologue: My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die. I counted. It happened on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I'd ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-la. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of miles away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about time the four of us made that journey. I remember asking, "What's the difference between a trip and a journey?" and my father said, "Narnie, my love, when we get there, you'll understand," and that was the last thing he ever said. We heard her almost straightaway. In the other car, wedged into ours so deep that you couldn't tell where one began and the other ended. She told us her name was Tate and then she squeezed through the glass and the steel and climbed over her own dead--just to be with Webb and me; to give us her hand so we could clutch it with all our might. And then a kid called Fitz came riding by on a stolen bike and saved our lives. Someone asked us later, "Didn't you wonder why no one came across you sooner?" Did I wonder? When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they're some kind of garbage, don't you know? Wonder dies.Powerful, isn't it? I won't lie...Jellicoe Road is a difficult read in many different ways. But worth it? Yes! Resoundingly yes! Why is it difficult? It weaves two stories together. The stories are seemingly unconnected...at least in the beginning. And because you--the reader--don't know what is going on...it's easy to get frustrated. Easy to get confused. We've got the past--from which the prologue serves as an introduction--and the present. (In a way it reminds me of Tamar.)The present. We've got several teens whose lives intersect--Taylor Markham, Ben Cassidy, Jonah Griggs, Chaz Santangelo, Raffaela, Jessa McKenzie--of whom Taylor is the main character. Taylor doesn't know where she fits in, "One day when I was eleven, my mother drove me out here and while I was in the toilets at the 7-Eleven on the Jellicoe Road, she drove off and left me there. It becomes one of those defining moments in your life, when your mother does that. It's not as if I don't forgive her, because I do" (20). Taylor is one of many students at Jellicoe School, a boarding school; she's the leader of her dorm or "house". (There are six houses.) And the school tradition is that there are "wars" between three sects--those that live at the boarding school (led by Taylor), the Townies (led by Chaz Santangelo), and the Cadets (led by Jonah Griggs). These wars involve territories. And these games last six weeks or so. And they're a big deal for those involved. But what at first seems like a senseless, pointless book on children playing war--tactical strategies, trapping, pranking, and such--soon turns into an emotional journey of the heart, soul, and mind.Taylor Markham is concerned, worried, anxious about Hannah, a woman who is the closest thing she has to family, when she disappears without a word. One day she's there, the next day she's gone. And Taylor can't get a straight word out of any of the adults around at the school or in the town about Hannah's whereabouts. Taylor--though Hannah is still missing--likes to take refuge in Hannah's house. She loves to read Hannah's manuscript, for example, which is the story of five kids who live on Jellicoe Road: Tate, Narnie, Webb, Fitz, and Jude.I don't want to spoil this one in any way. But I think this *may* help readers out a bit. I didn't catch on that the italicized portions--the stories of Tate, Webb, Narnie, Jude, Fitz, etc.--were written down stories. That Taylor was reading something Hannah had written down. I'm still not sure all of them are meant to be. But I think some of them are. And it is these stories which help Taylor to piece everything all together. (I had assumed that they were flashbacks. That they were there for the reader's benefit, but not for the characters within the book.)This is a book that had to grow on me. It wasn't one that I knew I would love--or thought I would love--from the very first page. But by the time the story comes together, by the finale, it had me completely won over. The story is intricately told and well written. Haunting, yes. Bittersweet, definitely. But one that I think is worth reading and recommending.© Becky Laney of Becky's Book Reviews

Maybe it's because I don't really like the reader on the audiobook version of this that I was going through, but I am not really a fan of this book. I couldn't get into it, so several chapters in I abandoned it.

Taylor Markham is a lost girl. Abandoned by her mother six years ago, she lives at the Jellicoe School and has no knowledge of her family. As the story slowly unravels, Taylor learns about her past and the origins of the war games that kids at the Jellicoe School play with the Townies and the Cadets. There are two story lines - Taylor's present day struggle to figure out her family situation and find herself, and the story of what happened on Jellicoe Road 20-odd years ago. It's a complex novel and there's a lot to like about it. There's a nice romance and some really great characters. The first half of the book was confusing and frustrating and I would have put it down if I weren't urged to finish it by my fellow Cybils panelists. Eventually everything gets explained, but for me it took too long for everything to come together and the book was too long overall. Lots of people have loved this book, but for me the resolution wasn't worth the frustration in the first half.

For the first half of this book, I could not figure out what all the hype was about. I couldn't keep all the characters placed, I couldn't figure out why in the world these boarding school kids were having some kind of war, and couldn't figure out what the hell Taylor's attitude problem was all about. Then, I hit the halfway point. And I couldn't put it down. This book is about love and friendship and families. It's about facing tough situations and realizing that sometimes there's more to your history then the things you can remember. It's a relationship book--about characters more than action or a particular plot. And it is lovely. I really liked it a lot.

Although I had a very hard time getting into this story, I found that it was so worth the effort once all the fragments of people and circumstances started weaving together. The story is like a puzzle, and all the more engaging for it. Now that I've finished, I have to go back to the beginning and pick up pieces I missed throughout the beginning before I knew who everyone would become later. If this doesn't make any sense, READ THE STORY.......you'll be glad you tried it!

Published in the US as Jellicoe Road. Winner of the 2009 Printz Award.Like many of the reviewers here, I was confused by this book for the first 100 pages. I could tell that the seemingly disparate stories of Taylor and her struggle to lead her House during the Territory Wars and the flashback sequences of a tragic car accident on Jellicoe Road, were connected, but it takes time for the stories to merge. This book contains every taboo subject possible: teen pregnancy, parental neglect, drug abuse, violence, and prostitution. I am not sure that this book is appropriate for any young readers under the age of 16 or so. Having said that, Jellicoe Road is a fantastic book. If you love YA literature because you like to read it yourself, this is a must-read. It is memorable.
Beautiful book. Difficult and heartbreaking but ultimately uplifting.
A bit melodramatic, but still very touching.

The more I reread, the more I fall in love with this book. Like a lot of people, I found this book to have a very slow and confusing beginning and it wasn't really until I got about halfway into it that it became a real page-turner. But when I finished I couldn't get it out of my head so I reread it and now I am convinced that, yeah, this really is an amazing book. I love Melina Marchetta's style. Her characters feel so real and true and they are always incredibly likable. Taylor and Griggs such memorable characters. After reading Saving Francesca and Looking for Alibrandi I can honestly say that Marchetta is simply a fantastic writer. This book is even more developed and mature than the others and it really does require the reader to reread for full understanding and appreciation. I adored this story and continue to reread my copy (I bought one!) but I do have to caution other readers that this isn't the most linear storytelling and you have to be patient. It's also not a book that I would recommend to younger teens -- I think there's a certain level of maturity that this book requires of the reader.

This is undoubtedly one of my favorite books of all time. I love the poetry, the mystery, and the fact that it's meant for "young adults." I bought this book while in Australia, read it when I was slaving away for an English family cleaning house and horse stalls for a few weeks, and cried like a baby all the way through. Since then I've read it probably six more times. It's not very long, and was an easy read out loud to my roommates (they said they enjoyed it, I swear). The story takes place out in the "bush" of Southeastern Australia and delves into the emotional plight of two generations of teenagers from this town, which all stems from one horrible car wreck that happened along the Jellicoe Road. Although the beginning is confusing at first, it's well written, super fun, and incredibly tragic.

I love how strange this book is, and how I was probably almost halfway through the book before the setting and the characters started to come into focus. I ended up being very swept up in it, and even cried at the end. Still not sure how much broad appeal it has for young adults, but it is a great story. I am looking forward to checking out this authors other books.

About a dozen swear words (the f word a couple times). There is teenage sex, but very briefly and not in great detail.This book has a slow start. There are two plots from two time periods and two groups of friends, that, by the end all fit together. But until pieces start to click into place in your mind, it's completely confusing.

Teen fiction. I know this won an award and everything but I just got tired of waiting for the author to give me some details--there were just too many mysteries surrounding the main character and her quasi-caretaker and without that framework to fit them into I didn't much care to hear the details of their everyday lives.

What I learned from this book is that it is a huge payoff novel. That means it all comes together at the end in a huge way. Which is great because I found the beginning hard to get into, but I had the feeling (plus a friend told me) that it was totally worth sticking with it. And it was. It's also a book that begs to be reread, and if I had the time, I would totally do that just to catch all of the nuance and stuff I missed the first time.
I liked this book - it kept me interested through the whole thing. There is a bit of swearing.

I don't get the hype, really. I didn't find the characters compelling or interesting. To be totally honest, I thought it was quite predictable. Although I clearly didn't figure out *everything* at the end, I knew from page 5 that the characters in the manuscript were somehow the ones acting in Taylor's history. So, that said, no shock.I thought that there was no reason to care about Taylor. We know little about her for 300 pages, except that she's got mommy fixation. Even in the end, I still didn't care about Taylor nor understand why I should care about her. I felt like the last 100 pages were the best in the book in terms of writing, action, and story. I wish a lot at the start could have been cut OR could have been better fleshed out in terms of character development. I think there were too many characters without any defining features who just became names to me. All of that said, I think this book definitely would have its readers. I think a lot of reluctant readers would have a hard time with this one because it requires reading the whole book. I think it might even require two readings. In terms of writing, Marchetta can paint some nice images for sure. She can also paint quite brutal ones. Sensitive readers might be put off by this one, since it's quite brutal in parts. Alas, the book earns a 3 star because I might, in the future, reread it to see if I missed something. If a book I don't care for a whole lot can compel me to consider rereading, then maybe something's there. I'm not quite sure why this one, out of many other great contenders, achieved the Prinz. But, I'm also not on the committee :)
This is a novel that I am legitimately sad I will never again get to read for the first time. Everything about it is beautiful and painful and redeeming and yes. More complete review to come.

I love Marchetta, and I'm so happy that this won the Printz Award! It took me a long time (a few weeks of picking at it while I read other books) to get through the first half of the book, and it was a challenging read, but I think the slow-ness fault was more mine than the book's. I know that Marchetta's books are always emotionally packed, and I could probably tell from the very beginning just how heart-wrenching this one would be at the end. I guess I wasn't ready for it a few weeks ago. Once it sucked me in halfway through, there was no way that I could put it down. This is definitely one that I'd re-read, to watch how it all unfolds, from the vantage point of knowing where it's headed. Beautiful! Great job Printz committee! If I had read this last year, it definitely would have been one of my 2008Favorites. I'd probably give it 4 1/2 stars if I could, but I'm going to round up. I guess this might be a mild spoiler, so stop reading if you don't want to hear anything, but... If you want to see a picture of Taylor and Webb in a tree, drawn by a teen and posted to the web, go to Marchetta's GR page (used to be up in 2009, when I wrote this review, but not there anymore--not at her website either).

This books is by far one of my favorite that I have read this year. I was a little confused at the beginning, but once I discovered that there were two stories going on, I really got into it. I love how the two stories come together at the end. Taylor is a character that readers can relate to, especially when she is showing her true emotions. I agree with the Printz committee members! This is definitely an award winning book!

Taylor’s mother drove hundreds of miles to abandon Taylor on the Jellicoe Road when she was 11. Now 17, Taylor is the reluctant leader of the students at the Jellicoe School in a territory war against the Townies and the Cadets. If she didn’t already have enough on her plate, Hannah, who is the closest thing Taylor has to family, has disappeared, leaving only a story she wrote about five kids who lived on the Jellicoe Road 18 years ago. Where did Hannah go? Why does the aloof Jonah Griggs, leader of the Cadets, seem to know Taylor better than she knows herself? Who is the mysteriousboy who sits out on a tree every night in Taylor’s dreams? What about the Hermit who once whispered something in Taylor’s ear? As pieces of the puzzle reveal themselves., it soon becomes clear that there is a connection between Taylor’s mysterious past and Hannah’s story.2009 Michael L. Printz Award Winner.

You only think this book is about territory wars, but it's really about love and discovery and history and the way you define yourself by the people you choose to love.This is a leap of faith book. It's not compelling for ~200 pages, but you need to push on, because around page 200, where it clicks--it's just brilliant. It's the only book I've ever finished reading and then immediately started reading again.And let me tell you--those first 200 pages? Reading them in the context of the rest of the book? They are just BRILLIANT.Read this book. Stick with it, even when you want to put it down. I promise you will not be dissapointed.

This book (current Printz award winner) is not technically a mystery, except for the mystery of Taylor's past, which is slowly revealed throughout the book. It takes place in Australia, at a school on the Jellicoe Road, where Taylor is a senior and head of house at the Jellicoe School. The first 6 weeks of the school year, when the Cadets are training nearby, there are territory "wars" between the Houses, the Cadets, and the Townies. There's a lot of tension in this story between the characters as well as Taylor's mysterious past from before the time her mother left her at a Seven-Eleven on the Jellicoe Road when she was 10. It kept me reading, and had a satisfying ending.

This is a Printz that I actually didn't hate with a burning passion - impressive. I liked the idea for this story, but at times I felt it was a little random, and I wasn't sure how things were going to add up at the end. The beginning was really weird and I was trying to adjust to how the story was moving along and keep track of all the characters. The backstory that was interwoven throughout was really intriguing and I kept reading because I wanted to know what had happened. The ending was unsuspecting, but still fulfilling. I wouldn't recommend this book to everyone because some of the content was objectionable and it wasn't as fast moving of a story as I would have liked. It had potential though, it just needed a little bit more tweaking to have made it a really good read.*Taken from my book reviews blog: http://reviewsatmse.blogspot.com/2009...

I'm torn between 3 and 4 stars. Started out confusing, then became predictable. Interesting story, if somewhat depressing. Seemed like no one was ever really happy in the story, at least not for long. Tragedy all around, and Taylor's narration showed her to be a serious, grumpy girl, yet everyone seemed to love her. Hmm. Ended on an optimistic note, so that helped.If I hadn't been so busy and tired lately it wouldn't have taken me so long to read this, and maybe I would have liked it more. But maybe not. The bad language threw me. I thought it was unnecessary and distracting, and made me like the characters less. Intriguing plot, though.

I will freely admit that I didn’t really get hooked on this book until I was over a hundred pages in. In fact, this is a book I have picked up and started several times before and ended up putting it down. I think the only way I got through it this time is because I made a commitment to read it, and I am so glad I did. Jellicoe Road is a story about tragedy and triumph, family and friends, hope and loss. It tells the story of two families, the Markham’s and the Schroeder’s, and their lives on the Jellicoe Road. Our primary narrator for the novel is Taylor Markham, who was abandoned by her mother at a 7-eleven on Jellicoe Road when she was 11 years old. As Taylor reluctantly accepts a leadership role at her school and leads the war against the townies and cadets, she also starts down a path of self discovery, where she discovers her own history and who she really is.Nothing in this novel is as it seems and it takes quite a while for the pieces of the puzzle to begin to fall into place. Once you get to that part, though, it becomes nearly impossible to put the book down. Highly recommended.Cautions for sensitive readers: There is some profanity in the book and some sexual situations. There is also a violent car accident that is referred to with some graphic depictions.
This was initially hard to get into, but once I began to understand its structure, I was hooked. Complex and intriguing.

Wow, this book was amazing. I'd give it a nine out of ten because I don't think it would really appeal to EVERYONE and the beginning is a bit slow, but I thought it was just a terrific book. I loved watching the pieces click together, and I liked all the character - flawed but lovable. This is the best Printz book I've read; even beats out Looking for Alaska for me.
Still not sure about the Printz award, but in the end I did like it. The multigenerational nature of the story and the complexity of how the plot ties together both make this one worth reading.

I didn't finish this book. Jellicoe Road is the Printz Award winner for 2009, and I'm not sure why. I thought this book was very confusing. It has two storylines, both taking place along Jellicoe Road 18 years apart. Along with that, there is a confusing element of three groups of teens who are at war with each other, constantly negotiating boundaries and getting back at each other when boundaries are crossed--this was never explained in the first 196 pages that I read.I _much_ preferred Nation by Terry Pratchett to Jellicoe Road.

I gotta say that at first I was thrown by the story - completely confused! But as I kept going I completely got it. The story is written expertly well - stunning, poignant, effectual, and sad but beautiful. Everything is measured very well, with nothing superfluous about it. I can't possibly summarize the story and do it any justice, because that is the main point of reading the book. I will say that Taylor is a young girl who was abandoned by her mother on the Jellicoe Road when she was 11 years old. Since then she has been living in a boarding school. Slowly she begins to piece together her past with the help of her friends and other adults in her life. I know now why it was chosen as the Printz winner. There is everything to appease all - teen girls, teen boys, adults, mystery lovers, and those who enjoy realistic fiction as well. I would highly recommend this read.

For the first half of this book, I kept wondering how this book won the Printz award. But once the second half started, I could not put this book down and it all started to make sense. I really enjoyed it. At some point, I will have to re-read it.

It took me a few chapters to get into this one. The author purposefully leaves a lot of loose ends which creates suspense later in the book. By the end, I fell in love with the characters and couldn't put it down.

I think that if I hadn't enjoyed Saving Francesca so much and if this book hadn't won the Printz, I would have put Jellicoe Road down around page 100. In those first hundred pages I had about zero understanding of what was going on, who these people were, or why I should care. But I kept reading and all of that worked itself out.Marchetta is a gifted writer, and she tends to work this slow burn thing to perfection. So if you pick this up please work up the patience to just keep going. Its worth it in the end.

I reviewed this late in 2008 for School Library Journal and found it complex, rich, and ultimately rewarding, but I am still surprised that it won the Printz Award. I would love some good reads types to read it and let me know what they think."School Library Journal (December 1, 2008)Gr 8 Up-For years, three factions-Townies, Cadets (city kids doing a six-week outdoor education program), and Jellicoe School students-have engaged in teen war games in the Australian countryside, defending territorial borders, negotiating for assets, and even taking hostages. Taylor Markham, a 17-year-old who was abandoned years ago by her mother, takes on leadership of the boarding school's six Houses. Plagued with doubts about being boss, she's not sure she can handle her Cadet counterpart, Jonah Griggs, whom she met several years before while running away to find her mother. When Hannah, a sort of house mother who has taken Taylor under her wing, disappears, Taylor puzzles over the book manuscript the woman left behind. Hannah's tale involves a tragic car accident on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years earlier. Only three children survived, and Taylor discovers that this trio, plus a Cadet and a Townie, developed an epic friendship that was the foundation of the many mysteries in her life and identity, as well as of the war games. While the novel might put off casual readers, patient, thoughtful teens will remain to extract clues from the interwoven scraps of Hannah's narrative, just as Taylor does, all the while seeing the collapse of the barriers erected among the three groups over the years. Elegiac passages and a complex structure create a somewhat dense, melancholic narrative with elements of romance, mystery, and realistic fiction.-Suzanne Gordon, Peachtree Ridge High School, Suwanee, GA Copyright 2008 Reed Business Information."
Okay so this book started out a little confusing and jumbled, but once I figured out what was going on, I couldn't put it down. I actually had it in the car and was reading at red lights!

taylor markham's mother left her at the 7-11 on jellicoe road when she was eleven years old. six years later, she is settled in at the local boarding school, head of her dorm, and watched over by a mysterious woman named Hannah who lives in a half-finished house near the river. taylor has also been placed in charge of her school for the territory wars: the boarding school, the cadets (military school students who camp in the woods), and the townies have divided up the area and continue to invade and negotiate for land, buildings, trees, etc. but when hannah disappears with no goodbyes, taylor can't concentrate on the wars. she's sure hannah has a link to her mother, who has a link to her father. but it turns out that the one with taylor's links is jonah griggs, the leader of the cadets who taylor shared a past incident with. and so the negotiations for land become negotiations for information, and even friendship, as the leaders learn the history of their war and the history of taylor markham.this book was off to a bit of a slow and confusing start, but the confusion was such that i wanted to keep reading. 15 pages in i was hooked and by the end, in total agreement with the printz award committee. highly highly highly recommended.
it really took me awhile to get into this one, very complicated plot- i felt like i need to start a character list, i would only recommend this one for the most avid teen readers

Melina Marchetta, between this and "Saving Francesca" - you are my hero. The characters, the tone, the pace, the emotional investment, the way the plot is laid out and tied together but not contrived. Insanely wonderful book. I'm only sorry I didn't read it earlier and push it at our Mock Printz. I should have known I'd love it.

This was a really different book, but after I read it I realized how much more interesting it was to me then a lot of teen books. There's a lot of subplots that take place within the main story, but I think that it would be a great book to discuss and I'm glad it was chosen as the Printz winner this year. Part mystery, part romance, some action (territory wars)...I think a book a lot of teens would enjoy.

Marchetta's writing is better than ever in this book that's confusing at first, then beautiful and brilliantly written. It's about family, friendship, hope and despair, not to mention enduring love. I wish all Twilight fans could read Jellicoe Road to discover how authentic romance is written.

You absolutely need to read Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchetta. It deserved the Printz award for sure and I was REALLY impressed. She weaves these stories together and the way it comes together in the end... fantastic. I feel like I spent the whole book trying to figure it out along with the main character, and the way it all finished was just perfect. Marchetta reveals just a little at a time and you need to know the whole story just as much as the protagonist. It's brilliant!I know this doesn't say much about the plot or what the book is about... but as others have said, this is a book you just have to read to understand. I was a bit lost for the first half of the book, trying to figure out what the heck was going on, and how these two different stories relate to each other. Once I made some connections, I couldn't put it down. Once you get past the initial feeling of "What the heck is going on and why should I care about it?" you transition to the feeling of "Now I really need to know what's going on!" Getting past the confusion and finally investing in the characters is absolutely worth it to see everything unravel and piece back together in the end.

VOYA Codes: S, 5Q, 3P.Jellicoe Road was simply one of the best books that I read for this class, or within the last year. I am a sucker for braided narratives; they read like a mystery novel for me. This was a great one. I found myself jotting notes to try to figure out how the plot lines connected long before it was evident there was much of a connection. I think that once students get into it (it does take a while for some, although I was instantly hooked) they will feel the same and try to think about how it will fit as well.So, assuming that not all teens are as into that aspect as I am, why else would this appeal to students? The novel begins with a brutal accident, one that can't help but make you root for the children who were left behind. On the other hand, the book is full of the closest types of friendships forming... The kinds of friendships that become family, whether out of need (as is shown here) or just because everyone needs that kind of bond. High school students are beginning to experience that, and to see groups of peers so passionate about friendship is something everyone can relate to... even if it's just something they have always wanted.However, I quickly learned that not everyone was as invested in reading this book as I was. Many of my classmates found the first hundred or so pages to be very confusing and therefore lost interest. For this reason, I would only really recommend it to students who love to read already. In addition, the "war" seems really pointless. Yes, it is explained later in the novel, but it actually makes most reviews sound like it's a science fiction novel or something, and it isn't at all. I think that this plot device, and the scant purpose for it, would distract and annoy many readers.The biggest asset to the best young adult literature is a believable cast of characters, and Marchetta is a little bit hit-or-miss on this one. Some, such as Taylor & Hannah, are incredibly believable. On the other hand, because so little is really known about all of the older cast of characters (particularly Fritz and Jude), these sometimes come off as flat characters, barely more than cardboard stand-ins.To encourage students to read this novel, I would suggest it readily to those who are fans of John Green's Looking for Alaska. Like that already-popular novel, Jellicoe Road addresses boundaries (perhaps more literally) and finding oneself, as well as coping with losses and finding meaning in others. Additionally, the more I read, the more Narnie reminded me of Melinda Sorvino in Laurie Halse Anderson's novel Speak. I was relieved to see that like Melinda, Narnie pulled herself together when crisis dictated that need.

This review is going to sound just like all the other reviews on Goodreads for this book, because they're all exactly right.It's a slow and confusing start: push through.It's frustrating, because Marchetta makes you work for every piece of information: it's worth it.It's an incredibly satisfying ending, even if you still haven't quite worked out all the details: yep, you're probably going to want to reread this one.I had put off reading this one because I thought it couldn't possibly live up to the hype - and it didn't, really. The hype was pretty impossible to live up to. But it's an incredibly well written book, full of complicated characters, with a story that will grip you before you ever figure out what's going on.(I ended up reading this in one sleepy go, trying to stay awake all night at the train station - turns out that when they say the train leaves at 11:20, they mean it. So plot and characters and style were a bit irrelevant, as I was going to read the book no matter how good or bad it was. But it worked out really well for me.)January 2011: I just reread this in full for the first time since I read it originally (I flipped back through it and read specific parts after finishing it the first time, as I bet lots of readers do, as I put things together), and I think it was even better this time around. Since I technically knew who everyone was this time around, and knew how the pieces came together, I think it was actually a better read this time around, because I caught more of the hints and details that I missed initially. And, seriously. Jonah Griggs. <3

Wow. This is a book that really makes you work for it. The first hundred pages are set-up, and a little hard to get through because they seem to be all over the place, telling a dozen different stories. Then something clicks, and you can start to see that all the stories fit together, but you don't really figure out how until the story is finished pulling you along. I can see why this won the Printz, and I'm very glad I stuck with it.

Once I got started, it was nearly impossible to put Jellicoe Road down. In the spirit of full disclosure, I will say that I loved Marchetta's previous novel, Saving Francesca, so much that as soon as I finished reading it, I started back at the beginning. Okay, so I was on an airplane, but I did have another book.17-year-old Taylor Markham has lived at a boarding school on Jellicoe Road since her mother abandoned her at a 7-Eleven six years earlier. She is an appealing narrator, so filled with pain that my eyes welled with tears as she pushes people away left and right. But she is true to herself and she knows she has been loved and she clings to that as she tries to unravel the mystery of her life. Meanwhile the reader is trying to unravel the mystery that opens the book, and of course the two mysteries converge beautifully.

Friendship, commitment, love and tragedy resonate in this award-winning teen novel set in Australia. Although difficult to get into Taylor's world of the war between the Townies, the Cadets, and the Jellicoe Boarding School kids, the interconnected interludes of the tragedy and its afteraffects become the primary focus of the latter half of the novel which make it all complete. The protagonist, is abandoned by her mother much like Holly was in Siobhan Dowd's Solace of the Road. Also the first part reminds me of The Disreputable History of Frankie Landau-Banks by E. Lockhart, set in an elite US boarding school. The road-trip to Sydney is eye-opening for Taylor, but ultimately the story is an emotional and coming-of-age trip rather than an actual road-trip.

This was a fabulous book. The reason why it didn't get 5 stars was that the first part of the story was a bit confusing. It was a bit liked you jumped into the middle of a story and then had to scramble about to figure out what was going on. However, by mid book, I was gripped. I would recommend this book to anyone.

I spent the first half of the book thinking to myself, why in the world did this win the Prinz? I felt like the story was plodding along much too slowly and I was confused about what was going on. Then all of a sudden everything came together and I couldn't put it down. From reading other people's reviews, I see that I'm not the only one who felt this way. In the end I really enjoyed Jellicoe Road and I see why it won. I'm torn however about that first half though. I want to think that it is an artful and deliberate slow buildup but I'm not really sure.

What a wonderful story! At first I was so confused...I misread or misunderstood something and was a little worried that I would feel that way the whole book...but I kept going, and the story just kept getting better. I love the way the 2 [3?:] stories came together, and slowly unraveled and intertwined. I can't wait till this arrives at my high school so I can get some kids to read it!

Printz Award, huh? Hmm. The mystery surrounding Taylor's past is gripping, and the personal connections between the characters are deep and raw--the best part of the book. Marchetta spends too much time on the Townies-Cadets-Houses boundaries war in the beginning; I thought it was a "crazy adventures at boarding school" book for a while. Throughout the novel, I didn't have a vivid sense of place, either. Again, both generations of characters will stick with me, but the actual events of the narrative are fast leaving my head. The writing is good, not outstanding... I think both _Octavian II_ and _Tender Morsels_, Printz Honor Books for this year, were better.
This started slow, but was absolutely engrossing by the end.

Michael Printz, Controversial 5Q 3P S. 'WAR, Huh Good God, What is it good for? Absolutely nothing...Say it again.." Since the author decided to incorporate songs that seemed to have barring on the psyche of the characters in the book, I thought I would take a moment to incorporate my own song to explain the book in it's entirety. I loved this book. I loved the braided narrative, which leads to the mystery behind Taylor. At one time I began to write down the names of everyone to link them to lovers, friends and family members, so I could remain focus and solve the mystery for myself. Never at any point did I think Jessa’s father was the Hermit…Marchetta was very careful to throw my sent. I do have to admit my mouth did drop, when Marchetta described the love-making scenes, while I did not think they were written too graphically I was just surprised by the elaborate words of anger, and sadness mixed with love. I guess, I found it surprisingly accurate compared to other writings where it is so romantic and over-rated. I liked the fact Marchetta wrote so ‘Raw’ and organic. Because this book was so hard to get into, I would only recommend it to Teens or people who LOVE to read. There was just so much detail lost about the Territory Wars, I was confused for the first 100 pages. And then throughout 200 pages I seriously wondered what the wars were for, and then when the original five described it as a game, I got it…but I think it would have been a lot easier to understand if it was described in the beginning. And I am still a little confused how Webb was shot out of the tree and his body was never found…what did Fritz do with the body?Overall, I loved this book and found the characters well developed and the language pretty fluid for more mature readers.

This was a challenging read. It took a long time for me to be able to discern what was fantasy, delusion, dreams, memoir, etc. but the way I could tell that it was a really good read was that I was willing to continue even though I didn't know these things because the writing - characters, setting were so well written. I have been a fan of Melina Marchetta's other works - Looking for Alibrandi & Saving Francesca, but Jellicoe Road is a much more complex, thoughtful work. There were a couple of important plot details that I must have missed along the way (that would necessitate a spoiler alert, so I won't post here) that would benefit from a second reading. I read this in ARC form so that may have been part of the problem. All in all, I agree with the Printz Committee's assessment of this book as the 2009 Printz winner.

I was a little disappointed when this book won the Printz because I had never even heard of it before. But I wanted to give it a chance so I read it. I must say, I really did like this book. I liked how Taylor starts discover her past through the story and other kids. I like how the different groups come together and finds friendship rather than hate. This book actually reminds me a bit of Looking for Alaska because it shows tragedy and the outcome. Even though the Hermit wasn't a huge part of the book, I will not soon forget him and how his actions affect so many others. There is some sexual stuff so this book is for a mature reader.
Though it was confusing for the first 100 pages or so, as soon as it got going it totally sucked me in and I couldn't put it down!!

Ok, so I finally understood what was going on in this book and then I really began to love it. I've never read anything by Marchetta but I think I will now because she writes beautifully. I can't give this 5 stars only b/c it took me so long to figure out and I think that people could really get lost and not finish the book. I only did because I knew it won the Printz and I wanted to see why, and I'm glad I stuck it out. This is one of those stories that stick with you.

This one had to grow on me. I was confused and bored at first but by the end I couldn't not finish it. Marchetta, Melina Jellicoe Road 419 pgs. Harper Teen ~Language R, Sexual Content~R Violence~PG-13Jellicoe Road in Austrailia is the main character in this novel about finding who you are and the importance of family relationships. Taylor Markham, age seventeen, is the leader of a house of girls at a boarding school in Austrailia. Each Summer, the boarding school kids participate in territory wars with the Cadets (Summer camp attendees from the military academy in Sydney) and the Townies (kids from the local town.) The novel begins with a flash-back that grabs the reader’s attention immediately, however, when chapter 1 begins it is slightly disorienting and it takes a few pages for the reader to orient themselves in the world of Taylor. There is a mystery embedded in the narrative that may initially cause confusion among readers, but those who stick with the storyline will be highly rewarded. I personally had a hard time wanting to stay with the story but I loved how it all came together. This title won the Michael L. Printz award for 2009. There are 2 sex scenes that are descriptive and sensual but not highly graphic. The swearing is scattered throughout narrative and includes 10-15 “f” and several “a**.” I would recommend letting the public libraries house this one.HS NO Allison Madsen~Youth Services Librarian-SJO Public Librarian

Printz winner. I have many issues with this book: the "war" was poorly poorly done - sort of a plot driving after-thought. It exists but we won't really do anything with it. Almost all the adults in this book are totally irresponsible. I do not believe for one instant that two of the adult figures would have kept Taylor so far at arms (or longer) length. That the school is set up as it is with so few authority figures or people in charge is bogus. And the daily responsibilities of these teens are somehow not even a little in the way of the other things going on in their lives. That said. The plotting and the structure of this book are so interesting. Looking at other reviews, most readers complain that the first 100 pages are confusing (I agree). I don't think that was an accident. It is amusing to me that so many readers are so put off by that. The romance unfolds nicely and not necessarily predictably (and the 1st time paragraph might just be the best and most honest YA handling of a touchy topic). It is a great story and I liked it all the more for not being perfect.

This book deserved to win the Printz. It is one of the most unusual coming of age stories I have read. It had the vibe of being ScFi or fantasy at times but was not. I can tell nothing about it except you are drawn in right away; get very confused along the way and then figure it all out. It ends a little too pattly but then again there is lots of tragedy to balance this out. Well worth the journey, anyone interested in teen lit should read this book.

Not my usual sort of strange book. A bit of a mystery as two stories are told together and we come to learn that they are intertwined. It took me awhile to get into it and at times it was so intense I had to put it down, but later I picked it up again and finished it all in a rush. I'm glad I finished it. It simultaneously crushed my heart and made it feel full. Well deserving of the Printz. I'd recommend it for strong readers looking for something different and perhaps for people who like stories of unconventional families.

Wow. I really really loved this book. I started it really confused, because friends had told me that it's best to go in not really knowing much, and I spent the first 100 pages wondering what was going on. Interestingly, after I finished and read other reviews, it was just about universal to feel that way about the first 100 pages. Then it kicked into speed, and I couldn't stop reading at the end. I started rereading it the day after I finished it, and then those first 100 pages had a lot of meaning that I had missed in the first go round. I love every single character, and love the way that this book all ties into itself.

Slow to start... just dumps you into the story mid-way and it took me awhile to figure out what exactly was happening, but once I did I really enjoyed the story. Very sweet scene depicting a 'first time'...
Riveting... After I read the book, I immediately started reading it again...

I read this because it got good reviews and , by the way, won the Printz award. I didn't like it at all at first because it was too confusing. I couldn't get a handle on anything. But I finally got into it and at the end I opened back to the beginning and re-read the whole thing (quicker this time) and liked it a lot. I don't think you should have to read a book 2x to get it, so I don't it deserves the Printz, but...I did like it the 2nd time around. Taylor lives at a school on Jellicoe Road. She was left in Jellicoe by her mother at age 11. 22 years earlier, there was a horrible accident on the Jellicoe Road. How the accident and Taylor's life merge is the basis of the story.

Have you ever turned on the radio and its in the middle of a new song and you like the song for all the reasons you like music: rhythm, beat, lyrics, voice... but you really don't know what its about? like any of the songs from sgt.pepper, for example? so you want to listen to it again? That's what happened for me with Jellicoe Road. I think when i read it again, i will break with affection for these characters. First time though, i liked them amd felt for them, but i found it very challenging to map their live experiences and relationships; to the point of diminishing my appreciation for the story. an interestng reading experience.

This year's Printz Award winner...if I hadn't been determined to read it, I'm not sure I would have made it past the first 50 pages. I was completely confused with the flashbacks and strange border wars. About half way through I started to get a feel for the characters and what they were actually doing, and the last 100 pages, I actually started liking the book. It took some work though.

Although extremely tough to get into (I wanted to give it up after abut 30 pages), once Marchetta starts sprinkling in fragments of mystery and the reader develops the ability to figure out who and what time it is, this book takes a rather amazing turn for the better. She has a great ability to make you feel what the character feels, to make certain moments incredibly real.Certainly there are weak points, and perhaps it occasionally plays a game of upping the tragic level, but overall it's a spellbinding read--if you can convince yourself to get through the clunky first few chapters.

Loved it, but still think others *start cough papertowns end cough* were better Printz contenders. This book didn't really catch me until the middle, where it grabbed me and made me sob. I loved pretty much all the characters, which is a big accomplishment.

I can't believe I waited so long to read this even after it won so many awards and so many people recommended it to me. I guess I'd have to disagree with the common sentiment that it "grabs you from the very first page," since I started it and put it down multiple times after reading the opening hook (which is certainly gripping) and then getting thrown into a completely different story on page three. This is not a criticism of the technique -- it's just that I want to tell anybody else who has the same experience that you should JUST KEEP READING ANYWAY, OKAY?

My friend demanded that I read this book. She said to me that it 'changed her life, and she will read it every year - at least once - for the rest of her life'. This book I actually struggled to stay with for the first hundred, maybe a bit more pages. I didn't understand what all the fuss was about, and how Taylor Markham and her very confusing life would actually impact me or change the way I thought. After I got over the confusing stages, of trying to wrap my head around situations, and learning about each character - I fell in love with this book. I'd never wanted anything more then to just turn back all the pages and read it over and over again.I now understand what my friend meant when she said she'd read it every year at least once for the rest of her life. I'll more then likely do the exact same thing - I want to grow old with this book. I'm attatched.

I got on the library waitlist for this book because Amy kept saying it was amazing. The first fifty pages or so I really wasn't into it -- didn't like the main character, didn't really like the setup -- but I kept going because Amy had insisted.And I started to get into it, and the story became about so much more than the initial setup indicated, and the characters grew, and connections were made (narratively and relationally), and parts made me cry (in an "emotionally moving" way).I feel like a lot of the intensity [am being vague for spoiler-free-ness:] would seem melodramatic to a lot of readers, but it really works for me (which surprises me a smidgen -- though it probably shouldn't).

This book had excellent plot lines. However, it was definitely a bit confusing switching from one to the next. There were also a lot of characters and with the different plot lines I was lost half the time. This must be a similarity of Australian authors. Taylor Markham is such a stong seventeen year old who has lived her fair share of tragedies. It is amazing she turns out as well as she does. I did like the ending of this book, but don't want to give it away so I'll just say it was very appropriate. The biggest appeal of Jellicoe Road lies in the settings, both past and present, and the vivid description of Jellicoe Road.I think this book may be a bit difficult for young adults, but who am I to say a child cannot handle a book? It just depends what each teen likes in books and if they can follow a confusing book, then I would recommend it to them! The characters are believable, but there are just so many of them to sort out. I would promote this book to teens when doing a unit on Australia. It is a rather historical book that mentions many cities and towns of Australia. To conclude, I understand why this book was nominated as a Printz Book, but it is rather confusing and it would not have received my vote. I encourage those who are interested to try it!4Q3PJ

This is a fascinating and unusual story about a young girl who lives at a private school in Australia. Years ago, several teens invented a game of "war," in which Townies and members of a military school compete for turf against her school. She has been chosen to lead her school in the next war. But she is also dealing with being abandoned first by her mother and then by her closest adult friend at the school. There is a connection between her and the original band of teens who began the war and as the novel progresses, she slowly unravels these connections. An intricate novel about surviving abandonment and forging new relationships.

I enjoyed this book. I hadn't heard much about it until it won the Printz award. The storyline is a bit confusing at times, but I enjoyed the story, the characters, and the setting. It was worth reading.

For me the book finally became interesting once the story started coming together (around the 200's), but I'm not sure if I ever really enjoyed reading it or felt connected to the characters. Maybe I'll pick it up again some day...

I'm torn about the rating I want to give this book. If I was judging just on the 1st 150 pages or so, I would give it a 2. I didn't feel engaged by the characters or by the turf war and quite frankly, if this hadn't been a Printz award winner, I don't know if I would have had the drive to finish it. However, the last 200-ish pages are a 4.5 or 5 for me. I liked the way the characters' stories all mesh together and I like the journey that Taylor ends up taking.

Just got the Printz Award. The first half of this book is very confusing. I think this reflects the confusion of the main character. As the story progresses all the disjointed and random bits of the story fall into place on tiny bit at a time. Ultimately the characters fall into their places, settling with the past and facing the future.

If I'd been reading this, instead of listening to it in 30-minute increments on the walk to and from work, I think I would have been racing through the last several chapters. It just gets better and better, connections building on connections, pieces clicking into place. I really loved that about it—it has all the charm of Saving Francesca, and then goes further—smarter, deeper, more intricate. The narration absolutely added to the experience—Rebecca Macauley does a brilliant job with all the characters, especially the teen girls and boys. I was fully engaged—I laughed, I gasped, I ate up the Aussie accents.A great, different coming-of-age story.

The story started slow. I didn't really get into it until page 200, but then I just couldn't put it down. As the story progressed I started to appreciate the first half of the book that I didn't really like because I realized I missed so much foreshadowing it was ridiculous. I completely understand why it won the Printz, but I liked Disreputable History better.It was a fun read that made me think. I love that combination.

The dual narrative of the story takes a while to understand. The plot is somewhat confusing and the cast of characters and their relationship to one another is not clear at first. The writing is beautiful and the sense of place outstanding. Taylor Markham is a strong female teen character. Fans of John Marsden and the Tomorrow Series will enjoy this book.

I loved this book! I definitely deserves the Printz Award! In America, the title is just "Jellicoe Road" by the way. The story starts out very loose. It took me 3 days and about 80 pages to start to get into it and I was very glad I stuck with it. At first, it seems as if there are 2 different stories going on and I was sure they were connected, but I couldn't figure out how. Then as the story goes on, it starts to tighten up and the entire story becomes clear and fabulous! The way I felt about it reminds me of how I feel about The Book Thief even though the stories are completely different. Must be the Australian YA/Adult cross over feeling. I think anyone would enjoy this book. Not just teens.

Like everyone else has said you have to get through like page 200 to really understand what is going on. The writing is amazing, she sucks you in and you can't stop reading. The characters are so lovely and I just couldn't help but tear up at the end. Such a captivating read.

The scattered and seemingly disconnected scenes that populate the beginning of this novel mirror the mystery surrounding the origins of the protagonist, Taylor Markham. She has a spotted memory of her mother and perhaps her father. With excerpts of a "novel" that her caretaker, Hannah, is writing, Taylor knows she on to something, but what? In the meantime, there are territory wars to be fought between the kids from Jellicoe School, the cadets and the townies. As the people and events of this school year spiral out of control, Taylor knows that she is on to something: finding out who she really is. I was confused at first but went along for the ride. And late last night finishing the last page I was in awe. What a great novel. The writing, the characters (OH! Taylor and Griggs! Raffy and Santangelo! Jessa! Chloe P.! and the Brigadier!), the river by Jellicoe School--they live and breathe!

My first go at reading Jellicoe Road was slow and wrought with confusion. I really wanted to get absorbed by the story because so many of my YA librarian colleagues were in love with the book, but I only made it through about 100 pages before it was due back to the library. A few months later, I decided to give it another chance and I’m glad I did. This time I was enchanted by Taylor Markham and the almost magical outback world she inhabits. Marchetta has beautifully interwoven the scattered stories of Narnie, et al. with Taylor’s present, creating a subtle, but increasingly urgent, mystery for both Taylor and the reader. Clues dropped earlier in the novel don’t become apparent until the end when all the dialogue, memories, and interactions of the characters come together. In Jellicoe and its environs, she has created a tremendous sense of place that grounds the story and becomes its own character of sorts. The territory wars between the students, the townies, and the cadets reinforce the importance of place in the book. I did find it cumbersome at first to keep track of all the characters and their relationships, especially the kids in Hannah’s story, but it all becomes clear in the end. Overall, Marchetta crafted a timeless, enjoyable, and extremely captivating novel.

This book took awhile to get into. At first I was confused by the cast of characters, but eventually figured them out. There seems to be several stories within stories going on in it that eventually interweave into each other. Once I got into it I enjoyed it, but it took awhile.

The characters in this book have stayed with me for days after finishing. I was a little confused in the beginning, but was still grabbed right from page one. I'd say this is a book that both teen boys and girls will enjoy, except the ending is kind of girly and neat, which I don't mind, but some teens might. Really well written and engaging.

Jellicoe Road is really two stories in one: the events of twenty-two years ago and how they affected five friends, and the senior year of Taylor Markham, who has a new position of power in the Territory Wars. The stories intertwine (through a manuscript that Taylor has read) and eventually intersect in ways that would seem pat in the hands of a lesser author. This is one of the most fantastic books I've read. It starts out slow, as Marchetta sets out the threads of all the story lines, but as you get further into the two time lines, you begin to match up events and people, so that by the end of the book, you immediately want to re-read it, just so you can lengthen that "Aha!" moment. Marchetta is a master at spooling out details, things that seem insignificant, until they suddenly become very important. She does this in such a way that although you may not take very much notice of this or that small detail, when the revelations come, you remember what came before very clearly - so that the process of piecing these stories together isn't a strain on your memory or patience. Marchetta has always been one of my favorite authors in terms of what she understands about teenage girls, and she manages to get humor, sorrow,love, action, romance, and mystery all packed in, without being melodramatic or overbearing.Please, please give this book a chance - you'll be well rewarded if you stick it out.
The disjointed threads all weave together in the end.

I rarely give out five stars, that is reserved for books that really, really catch me. Books that make me look at the world differently or that just speak to me on some level I wasn't expecting. Jellicoe Road did all three. This is a beautiful, haunting book and I know the characters will remain with me for a long time. The characters are what make this book shine and they are so well done! Marchetta creates characters that leap from the page and feel like friends you might have known in school. The descriptions are beautiful and lyrical. The pace is at times fast, at times leisurely and slow, but always moving forward with a sort of inevitability that does not feel forced or contrived. Taylor Markham is trying to unravel the secrets in her past, to find where her guardian has disappeared to. At the same time, the tale of five friends who met on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years before unfolds along side Taylor's. As the two stories overlap and weave together the narratives combine into one remarkable, tragic and redemptive story that feels true and deep. This is definitely going on my permanent book shelf and will be read again.

A book about growing up without parents, about friendships and relationships and loss and grieving. It has car crashes, "war" between cadets, townies and students, mysterious boys in trees, and other intriguing details. It took me a while to get into it, because there are a lot of characters to keep track of, both in present day and in a novel manuscript that the main character is reading. So you might want to have a scorecard handy. But it's totally worth it, as the characters start to intertwine and the levels of story get deeper. There are a lot of twists and surprises, and plenty of emotion. A really unique book. Winner of the Printz Award 2009.

I can definitely see why this was the Printz Award winner for 2009! It was one of the most original novels I've ever read. I think young women will especially like it. It deals with hard hitting issues like drug abuse, abandonment, self-hatred, and the pains of growing up in a difficult situation but also a little romance and love are thrown in to make it less heavy. At times it was confusing and hard to follow, but I'm sooooo glad I stuck with it. Bravo to Melina Marchetta!

This is a fascinating book. The adults are keeping a secret that just shouldn't be kept. It has almost ruined a young girl's life. But, at the same time, because of all the love for her she has survived. It is really two stories that entwine and end up together at the end. Almost 20 years ago, and today. I LOVE it!!

I don't think I'll be re-reading annually like I do with Saving Francesca--but I really enjoyed this. I may even love it...but I'm not ready to commit...I have to read it a few more times. It has everything you've come to expect (and love!) from Melina Marchetta--but it's probably the most complex of her novels to date. The beginning is very jarring and hard to sink into, but if you stick with it (and re-read the first few pages a few times) the end result is well-worth the initial difficulty. I highly recommend!
Very rarely do award-winning books agree with me, but this story was a revelation. Strange, beautiful, heartbreaking, compelling as all get out, and ultimately full of hope.

This is a wow book for sure. It starts off intriguing but confusing. The parts slowly fall into place as you journey, so don't give up. I loved how every detail the author gives you figures prominently into the two stories, and how the pieces come together all the way to the last page. The intricate weaving of the "fictional" story by Hannah and the protagonist's real life is reflective and seamless. Love, love, love and would highly recommend!

Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mom when she was 11 and raised in an Australian boarding school by den mother Hannah. When Hannah mysteriously disappears one day, the search for her leads Taylor to discover things about herself (past, present and future) and those that love her.Marchetta's latest work is well done, but I didn't fall in love with it like the Printz committee. I found the plot to be too neat, a bit melodramatic and I didn't like how everything wrapped up a little too well. But the character development (particularly Taylor and Jonah) and the dialogue is great.Interestingly, I think the Printz committee must have taken teen appeal into consideration when they picked this book. I think teens will love the drama and how the puzzle fits together. It's definitely one I would recommend to teens.
So, so good. So much better than I expected. Highly recommend, especially if you like a bit of a mystery.
I would give this more stars if I could. I absolutely loved it.

Like many Goodreads readers, I was confused for at least the first half of this book. Although everything came together eventually, I feel like I never completely forgave the story for keeping me in the dark for so long. I also thought it was kind of strange that this was ostensibly a school story, yet the characters never seemed to go to class!

Good. Would be rated higher but much of the plot revolved around some pretty harsh situations. Taylor puts together puzzle pieces of her past and learns to love. The mystery of Taylor's past is skillfully revealed, bit by bit. Note to sensitive readers: some language and a couple of sex scenes.

Overall I really liked this book but I have to say it took at least 100 pages to really get what was going on and then the middle dragged on with all the "territory war" stuff...so I skipped a lot in the middle. But I LOVED the end and thus went back and read a lot that I had skipped.

I think this book would appeal to many teens because the central issues of the novel are timeless and cross cultural and racial barriers. I know that many people have been turned off by the confusion of the first few chapters, but I disagree, I think with the proper preparation, teens could really enjoy this book a lot. The book deals with the following developmental markers: surviving on your own/becoming independent, reconciling with your past, developing positive adult relationships, forgiveness, and understanding. I thought that the characters were believable. Taylor really appealed to me and drew me into the story. I wanted her to do well and succeed. I also liked the relationships amongst the characters; I thought they were realistic and believable. I was a bit doubtful that there would really be “territory wars” as described in the book, but upon understanding the history behind their creation, I can see how that would really happen too. In a sense, Taylor’s experiences could be a representation for the types of conflict that occur on a much larger scale around the world.
